	<item>
				<title>#EndTheWait – May 29 – Provincial Election 2014</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=10</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 30 May 2014 01:32:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=10</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong>Provincial Election Day </strong>in Ontario is <strong>Thursday, June 12, 2014</strong>. Please remember to get out and <strong>vote!</strong> For further information on <strong>WHO, WHEN, WHERE, HOW</strong> to vote, please go to the <strong>Elections Ontario</strong> website at <a href="http://wemakevotingeasy.ca/en/home.aspx">http://wemakevotingeasy.ca/en/home.aspx</a>.

Please also help Community Living Ontario to <span style="color: #ff0000;"><strong>#EndTheWait </strong></span>and sign our petition at <a href="http://chn.ge/1oUmxtd"><strong>http://chn.ge/1oUmxtd</strong></a><strong>   </strong>Please pass it along to friends, family, neighbours and co-workers. We’re happy to report that in just a matter of a few days, we already have 2,000 votes! Let’s keep those numbers of support climbing!

<img class="aligncenter size-full wp-image-14" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/petition.png" alt="petition" width="437" height="259" />

In this provincial election, we’re asking party candidates:
<blockquote><strong>"If your party is elected, would you commit to ending the wait for funding and supports for people who have an intellectual disability and stabilizing services by committing to the $810 million over three years promised in the proposed 2014 provincial budget?”</strong></blockquote>
Investment will:
<ul>
	<li>End the wait for daily living supports for children and adults which is almost 20,000 people long</li>
	<li>Begin to address the wait list of over 7,000 people who are waiting for support to live in a home of their own</li>
	<li>Deliver stability to agencies who provide front-line supports</li>
	<li>Develop new community-based services that support key life transitions</li>
</ul>
I have attached the Community Living Ontario’s <a title="Community Living Ontario Election 2014 Toolkit" href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/TZ_CLO_Elect2014Tlkit_R2a.pdf">Election 2014 Toolkit</a>. This toolkit provides you with information on how to engage with your local candidates during the election campaign and how to share practical recommendations about crucial issues. This toolkit also serves as a quick reference guide that supplies you with information and facts that you can share with people you speak to, whether it be a current MPP, an election candidate, or someone close to you. It is the starting point of change!

This election toolkit also provides helpful information on simple ways that you can <strong>take action</strong> in your riding and in your community. Party leaders and local candidates need to hear loud and clear that voters are concerned about securing supports and #<strong>ending the wait</strong> for people who have an intellectual disability, and their families, and that they will heavily weigh party platforms when they vote.

Please also make sure to <strong>‘LIKE’</strong> us on <strong>Facebook</strong> and follow us on <strong>Twitter!</strong>

Facebook and Twitter and our other social media platforms are a fun, interactive way for engaged and informed Community Living Ontario followers to share thoughts on issues and trends relevant to the disability sector.

We look forward to chatting with you and staying in touch!

<a style="margin: 0 20px 0 165px;" href="http://www.facebook.com/communitylivingontario"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-36" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/FB_FindUsOnFacebook-100.png" alt="Facebook &quot;Find Us&quot; icon" width="100" height="26" /></a><a href="http://twitter.com/#!/clontario"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-31" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/Twitter_FollowUs.png" alt="Twitter &quot;Follow Us&quot; icon" width="129" height="20" /></a>

There will be a televised Election Debate with the Party Candidates on the evening of <strong>Tuesday, June 3<sup>rd</sup>.</strong> <strong>Details TBA</strong>.

<strong>Contact Us</strong>

<a href="mailto:info@communitylivingontario.ca"><strong>info@communitylivingontario.ca</strong></a>

<strong>T. (416) 447-4348</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Liberal Party response to #EndTheWait Campaign questions</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=50</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jun 2014 19:33:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=50</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/liberal.png"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-52" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/liberal.png" alt="liberal" width="289" height="91" /></a>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">June 2, 2014</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Mr. Roy O’Leary</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">President</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Community Living Ontario chris@communitylivingontario.ca</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Dear Mr. O’Leary:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">As Premier, I became convinced it was essential for our Ontario Liberal government to address the urgent needs facing people with developmental disabilities and their families.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> That is why I supported our 2014 Budget proposal to make the largest investment in developmental services <em>ever</em> -- $810 million over three years, to end the wait lists for direct funding programs.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">When we announced this funding, the Progressive Conservatives said it was a waste of money.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">The NDP said nothing, and their recent platform continues to be silent on services for people with developmental disabilities. Moreover, they opposed the most progressive budget in decades, which included the $810 million investment in developmental services.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> If my government is given another mandate, we will absolutely reintroduce the budget and carry this forward as planned.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> This new $810 million investment, which would have begun to flow as early as September, would:</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> <!--more--></p>

<ul style="padding-left: 60px;">
	<li>Expand direct funding programs to help individuals with developmental disabilities participate in their communities:</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">o    Eliminate waitlists for the for the Passport program over four years; and</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">o    Eliminate waitlists for the Special Services at Home program over two years.</p>

<ul style="padding-left: 60px;">
	<li>Expand individualized planning to help individuals with developmental disabilities transition to adulthood, find employment and achieve greater independence;</li>
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left: 60px;">
	<li>Provide residential supports to adults with urgent needs, including support to transition young adults currently receiving youth residential services to more appropriate adult services and supports; and</li>
</ul>
<ul style="padding-left: 60px;">
	<li>Expand cost-effective residential services and promote innovative community living solutions that support greater inclusion of people with developmental disabilities into communities.</li>
</ul>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">People with developmental disabilities rely on hundreds of agencies across Ontario for a wide array of safe, high-quality services. We will invest $200 million over three years for the front-line workers in these agencies to ensure families have the services they require in their communities.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Specifically, this investment will support the continued professionalization of the community and developmental services sector and support salaries and wages for front-line workers, including those in lower wage bands. It will support overall transformation of the sector by providing agencies with the flexibility needed to modernize how they offer the right mix of services to vulnerable Ontarians.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Only the Ontario Liberal Party has committed to making this investment in the developmental services sector. The back-and-forth from the PC party on this issue demonstrates a lack of commitment to helping the most vulnerable in society. The reckless cuts being proposed would hurt the services we hold dear and plunge Ontario back into recession. As for the NDP, make no mistake – they opposed the $810 million investment in this sector. They had the chance to support the most progressive budget in decades, and despite advice from the community they chose to force us into an unnecessary election. The opposition have put this funding at risk for political gain, and the people we serve are caught in the middle.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">I am very proud to have brought these long-needed improvements forward and, given the opportunity, I’m determined to see them through.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Thank you for the important work you and your colleagues do.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Please accept my best wishes.</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Sincerely,</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> <a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/wynne.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-53" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/wynne.png" alt="wynne" width="315" height="72" /></a></p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Kathleen Wynne</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;">Leader of the Ontario Liberal Party</p>
<p style="padding-left: 60px;"> Premier</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Green Party response to the #EndTheWait Campaign questions</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=56</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Jun 2014 03:12:41 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=56</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/green.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-57" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/green.png" alt="green" width="310" height="94" /></a>

&nbsp;

Dear Chris,

I am pleased to be able to respond to your question on behalf of the Green Party of Ontario. Yes, the GPO, if elected, will commit to ending the wait for funding and supports for people who have an intellectual disability, and their families and stabilizing services by committing to the $810 million over three years as promised in the proposed 2014 provincial budget.

All the best,

Jessica

--

Jessica Higgins

Policy and Candidate Support Green Party of Ontario]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>NDP Response to the #EndTheWait Campaign questions</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=59</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Jun 2014 00:20:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=59</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[&nbsp;

<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ndp.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-60" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/ndp.png" alt="ndp" width="605" height="77" /></a>

June 01, 2014

&nbsp;

Roy O’Leary, President,

Community Living Ontario

240, Duncan Mill Rd. Suite 403

Toronto, ON M3B 3S6

&nbsp;

Dear Mr. O’Leary,

Thank you for your letter outlining Community Living Ontario’s priorities and concern for people with intellectual disabilities. The Ontario NDP shares your concern and is committed to investing to improve services and programs for those in need.

The Ontario NDP will provide the much needed funds to improve supports for those with developmental disabilities and their families. As part of our platform we are keeping the budget promises that we know are much needed and that we can deliver on.

In addition we will re-strike a Select Committee on Developmental Services to continue work on their important recommendations on how to improve these services. We will also work with families and stakeholders to implement their recommendations for families to have smoother and better access to services in the future.

In the 2014, budget the Liberals promised some much needed funding for developmental services. In fact, they made over 70 other promises, when they were not even able to keep three budget promises from last year. They are trying to escape their scandals by promising the moon and the stars and the NDP had some serious concerns about whether those promises would be kept – we’ve heard from people of Ontario who no longer trust them to keep their promises.

To answer your specific questions:

<strong>1. If your party is elected, would you commit to ending the wait for funding and supports for people who have an intellectual disability, and their families and stabilizing services by committing to the $810 million over three years as promised in the proposed 2014 provincial budget?</strong>

Yes

<strong>2. Our members wish to know, should you form government, what would you invest in the developmental services sector and over what time period?</strong>

We will invest an additional $810 million in the community and developmental services sector over the next 3 years.

Sincerely,

<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/sig.png"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-61" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/sig.png" alt="sig" width="242" height="74" /></a>

Monique Taylor

Ontario NDP Critic for Children and Youth Services

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Liberals refuse Elliott’s call for the release of the Select Committee’s Report on Developmental Services</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=86</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 14 Jul 2014 14:31:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=86</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img src="https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/?ui=2&amp;ik=a4ae1f874f&amp;view=att&amp;th=1473502d34c8a986&amp;attid=0.1&amp;disp=emb&amp;zw&amp;atsh=1" alt="Elliott-Banner" width="627" height="89" />

&nbsp;

FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE

&nbsp;

QUEEN’S PARK – Immediately following Question Period, Christine Elliott asked for unanimous consent to restrike the Select Committee on Developmental Services so that the Select Committee can release its Final Report. However, the Liberal government voted against the unanimous consent motion.

&nbsp;

“I am disappointed that the Liberal government is stalling the release of the Report. Thousands of Ontario families are waiting for it”, said Elliott.

&nbsp;

The Select Committee on Developmental Services began its work last October and has travelled throughout the province, hearings from hundreds of individuals and families that there is a clear need for change in the system.

&nbsp;

“The Liberals have promised $810 million for developmental services in their budget. The Committee’s Final Report contains recommendations for improvements in the system, which will offer good value for money and ensure that individuals and families receive the supports and services they desperately need. I simply cannot understand why the Liberals refuse to acknowledge the work of the Committee,” concluded Elliott.

&nbsp;

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wohvGp2f2o8

<strong>-30-</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>Contact: Laurel Brazill | Office of Christine Elliott, MPP | <a href="tel:%28416%29%20325-1331">(416) 325-1331</a></strong>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>liberals-refuse-elliotts-call-for-the-release-of-the-select-committees-report-on-developmental-services</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	<item>
				<title>CL Ontario&#039;s CEO Interviewed Following Developmental Services Final Report</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=105</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 23 Jul 2014 18:08:25 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=105</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[Our CEO <span style="color: #222222">Chris Beesley was interviewe</span><span style="color: #222222">d in today's Toronto Star article. The interview was in response to the long-awaited report from the Select Committee on Developmental Services. </span>

No more wait lists. One provincial minister in charge. And recognition that all people with developmental disabilities have the right to services throughout their lives. Those are the key recommendations in a long-awaited report released by the Select Committee on Developmental Services.

&nbsp;

“There is a lot we can work with in this report,” says Chris Beesley, CEO of Community Living Ontario, which serves about 12,000 developmentally disabled Ontarians, including about 9,000 in group homes at a time when 12,000 are waiting for beds.

&nbsp;

“Overall, we give it two thumbs up. Putting one minister in charge reflects the importance of a holistic approach,” Beesley added<strong>.</strong>

<a title="Chris Beesley Interview" href="http://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2014/07/22/no_more_wait_lists_for_disabled_in_ontario_says_allparty_report.html" target="_blank">Read the interview here!</a>

<a title="Final Report" href="http://www.ontla.on.ca/committee-proceedings/committee-reports/files_pdf/SCDSFinalReportEnglish.pdf" target="_blank">Read the Select Committee On Developmental Services Final Report </a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>105</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2014-07-23 14:08:25</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-23 18:08:25</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>community-living-ontarios-ceo-interviewed-by-toronto-star</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Community Living Ontario&#039;s Quarterly Report Q1- 2014/2015</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=111</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 28 Jul 2014 16:07:18 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=111</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<img class="alignnone wp-image-112 " src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/cloblogpost.png" alt="CLO Header" width="577" height="92" />

<strong>Quarterly Report - Q1 - 2014/2015</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>Mission</strong><strong>:</strong>

Community Living Ontario is a province-wide confederation, rooted in a strong network of individuals who have an intellectual disability, families, friends, member organizations and community partners. It will be guided by, adhere to and strive to achieve its Goal and Vision in all its actions. Community Living Ontario advocates, promotes and facilitates the full participation, inclusion and citizenship of people who have an intellectual disability.

<strong>                          </strong>

<strong>Vision</strong><strong>:</strong>

Community Living Ontario envisions a society where everyone belongs, has equality, respect and acceptance. This gives people a sense of self-worth and opportunities for growth. The gifts, uniqueness and innate value of each individual are celebrated, supported and acknowledged as essential to the completeness of the whole community.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Strategic Priorities</strong><strong>:</strong>
<ol>
	<li>Lead a comprehensive advocacy initiative for reducing poverty, powerlessness and exclusion in the lives of people who have an intellectual disability.</li>
	<li>Strengthen the Community Living Ontario Confederation.</li>
	<li>Increase the voice of people who have an intellectual disability</li>
</ol>
<!--more-->

<strong>Note: </strong>For the full strategic priorities document, refer to: <a href="http://communitylivingontario.ca/about-us/strategic-priorities-2011-2016">http://communitylivingontario.ca/about-us/strategic-priorities-2011-2016</a>

&nbsp;

Quarterly Report – Q 1 – 2014/15

&nbsp;

As part of our efforts toward increased transparency and accountability, we at Community Living Ontario are pleased to provide our Q1 report for fiscal 2014/15.

This is a new initiative for us, so the format might change over time, but the intent will remain; to give our members and other stakeholders, a snapshot of the work we’ve done over the past three months.

The first quarter was a typically busy one. I was fortunate in being able to visit with 18 of our agency members, listening, commiserating, talking and celebrating with many people, including persons being supported, Board members, staff and parents.

We initiated a work group, comprised of senior MCSS staff, ED’s from several of the DSO offices, myself, Gord Kyle, and Sherri Kroll, ED of Community Living Middlesex. The goal of this group is to examine the current structure of DSO across the province, in order to streamline the process and improve communication. We’ve met on several occasions thus far, and are very encouraged with the direction of these discussions.

Our #EndtheWait provincial election package and accompanying petition were very well received and utilized by our members. The petition has managed to attract over 2700 supporters so far.

Our Passport Mentoring program continues to connect youth with an intellectual disability, to mentors in their community who are willing to share their experience and interests with youth who are exploring who they are and what they want to do when they’re finished school.

Plans are well under way for this year’s conference, entitled “Together We’re Better” which is shaping up to be one of our best ever.

As our mission states, “Community Living Ontario advocates, promotes and facilitates the full participation, inclusion and citizenship of people who have an intellectual disability.” Everything we do needs to support our mission, values and strategic priorities.

I encourage you to get a cup of coffee or tea, read the next 7 pages and tell us what you think.

Sincerely,

Chris Beesley

CEO, Community Living Ontario

&nbsp;

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Social Policy Department</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>Addressing the Crisis being faced by Individuals and Families</strong>

&nbsp;

Community Living Ontario has been warning the government for years that a crisis is coming in the developmental services sector as thousands of individuals and families continue to wait for supports and services they need to live in the community.  We have called on government for significant new funding to drive a multi-year plan to address these challenges.  This spring we finally saw significant steps towards the kind of action we have been calling for.  The government’s Select Committee on Developmental Services released its interim report echoing the problems that Community Living Ontario and many others have been raising with government.  Additionally, the Government, in its 2014 budget promised $810 million in new funding to the sector over the next three years to begin addressing the problems identified.  While the provincial election delayed the release of the final report of the Select Committee and the implementation of the promised funds, we are confident that both will proceed and we will continue to advocate for this to happen.  We look forward to the opportunity to work with government to address the issues identified through the Select Committee and welcome new funding to help with this work.

&nbsp;

<strong>Addressing Issues with Developmental Services Ontario</strong>

&nbsp;

Community Living Ontario is committed to helping sort out the role that Developmental Services Ontario (DSO) plays in our communities.  Throughout the spring we met with representatives from the DSO Provincial Network and the Ministry of Community and Social Services to explore ways of addressing the challenges being experienced in the implementation of the DSO system.  We have explored mechanisms that would improve the experience of people and families who interact with DSO.  We are also working to help connect DSO better to community living organizations and other community supports.  We have also been exploring ways of formalizing a system of ‘Guided Personal Supports (GPS) that would ensure that people had a continuity of planning and access of supports throughout their life and would have access to the full range of opportunities and supports that our community has to offer.  This change would represent a significant step towards addressing the resolution passed by members at last year’s Community Living Ontario Annual General Meeting which calls on government to ensure life-long person directed planning and facilitation as a right to all who wish it.  Our progress to date has been shared with the Provincial Network on Developmental Services and we are looking to work with the government to broaden the discussion about these important matters with all stakeholders in the province and to begin to roll out positive reforms.

&nbsp;

<strong>Seeking Legal Reform for Supported Decision Making</strong>

&nbsp;

We have made excellent progress in recent months on our work to reform the legal frameworks pertaining to guardianship and substitute decision making. Over the past two years, Community Living Ontario has participated in two advisory groups with the Law Commission of Ontario, one looking at reforming the current legal framework for substitute decision making and the second looking at making it easier for a person to access the Registered Disability Support Plan when they are deemed to not be contractually competent to do so.  The RDSP group has wrapped up its work and a report with recommendations will be sent this summer to government regarding reform.  The second and broader process looking at overall substitute decision making has just completed a comprehensive public discussion paper that the Law Commission released in June.  We will continue to work with the Law Commission and the government to encourage the implementation of a legal framework for supported decision making that will benefit all who are at risk of being placed under guardianship.

&nbsp;

<strong>Administrative Justice Support Network</strong>

&nbsp;

We continue to build our capacity for supporting people who are facing tribunals or other administrative justice mechanisms.  Building on the launch last year of our comprehensive web resources that provide people information about a range of tribunals and other process, we are working now to build a network of mentors; people who have been through these processes in the past and are willing to stand beside others now facing a tribunal.  We held our first gathering of mentors in the spring to begin the orientation and training that they will need to be effective.  We continue to look for people who are interested in learning more about mentoring. Visit our Administrative Justice Support Network site here <a href="http://ajsn.communitylivingontario.ca/">http://ajsn.communitylivingontario.ca/</a>.  Through the Administrative Justice initiative, we are also proceeding with a project in collaboration with Community Legal Education Ontario. Beginning with a number of organizations in Southwest Ontario, we will be working to assist front-line workers in community living associations to be better prepared to provide advice to people they support about how to access legal and rights instruments, should a person ask them for assistance in doing so. We hope to expand this initiative to other parts of the province once it has been refined through the initial project.

&nbsp;

<strong>Doug Minty Inquest</strong>

&nbsp;

The inquest into the shooting death of Doug Minty by police wrapped up in June.  Community Living Ontario called for this inquest following the shooting in 2009 and acted as an intervener in the inquest.  Recommendations coming out of the inquest focused on helping police better understand that people who have an intellectual disability, like all others people, have unique and individual characteristics and personalities.  Through training and better communications, it is hoped that police will find ways of responding to calls that ensure the greatest degree of

Safety possible for all concerned. Community Living Ontario was retained and represented at the inquest by Iain Donnell of the Donnell Law Group and Orville Endicott, Legal Counsel for Community Living Ontario.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Communications &amp; Marketing</strong>

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Community Living Ontario Web Site</strong><strong>:</strong>

As a priority vehicle for pushing out and receiving information and as a tool to better communicate with our priority audiences, we continue to revise and update the Community Living Ontario Web Site.  We have entered <strong>Phase l</strong> of a major review process to make it more relevant, user-friendly and accessible.  As part of this process, we’ve submitted a project proposal to <strong>MCSS</strong> to have the Community Living Ontario web site translated into French.  We’re hoping to coordinate the <strong>Web site Rebuild/Redesign Project</strong> to include partnerships with some of our association members who may also be contemplating a web site redesign.

&nbsp;

<strong>Social Media</strong><strong>:</strong>

We continue to expand our social media outreach and presence via <strong>Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn</strong>, and new <strong>Instagram</strong>, <strong>Pinterest,</strong> and <strong>Google+</strong> accounts.  Metrics (via <strong>Klout</strong>, <strong>Google Analytics</strong>, etc.) that have been set up and designed to measure the results of our  ongoing communications efforts will be compiled and shared with key internal stakeholders.  We’ve also created a <strong>new Community living Ontario blog space</strong> at <a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog</a> ; another pathway and tool designed to help encourage people to join the conversation.

&nbsp;

<strong>Sponsorship/Partnership</strong><strong>:</strong>

We continue to pursue sponsorship/partnership opportunities with key corporate sponsors.  Moving forward, we will need to continually create new and varying opportunities/experiences for sponsors to participate with us on internal and external facing Community Living Ontario communications products (e.g. newsletter, CL Ontario Web Site, public-facing outreach campaign, Conference materials, etc.).

&nbsp;

<strong>Internal Communications</strong><strong>:</strong>

The redesign and re-launch of a new <strong>CEO Weekly Email Update</strong> template is to be completed by early September, 2014.  The Community Living Ontario Communications Audit is completed.  Results of the communications audit will be shared with key internal stakeholders including:  Board, Senior Staff, and key stakeholders, etc.  Launch of the new <strong>L-Soft</strong> email distribution listserv platform is in progress.

&nbsp;

<strong>Conference 2014</strong><strong>:</strong>

We continue to explore, develop and introduce new integrated communications and marketing strategies and promotional materials leading up to Conference 2014, including: a digitally-based Conference 2013/14 online Flyer; an integrated social media strategy; video-taped CEO introduction to the Annual Report 2013/14 for CL Ontario website; a series of themed video clips; video –taped ‘thank you’ for conference attendees; hyperlinked banner created for CL Ontario staff email signatures, among others.

&nbsp;

<strong>Fundraising:</strong>

We’re hoping to coordinate the <strong>Benevon</strong> fundraising program to include other Community Living association members and proceed to <strong>Phase l</strong>.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Media and News Releases</strong><strong>:</strong>

We continue to successfully extend and expand our reach out to key media outlets in order to help us communicate key messages to our external audiences.

<strong>Selected Media:</strong>
<ol>
	<li><strong> Yonge Street Media </strong></li>
</ol>
<a href="http://www.yongestreetmedia.ca/civicimpact/communitylivingontarioresponds04162014.aspx"><strong>http://www.yongestreetmedia.ca/civicimpact/communitylivingontarioresponds04162014.asp</strong>x</a>

	<li><strong> CTV (Video) </strong></li>
</ol>

&nbsp;

</ol>

<strong> </strong>

<strong> </strong>

<strong>News Releases:</strong>
<ol>
	<li><a href="http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1338173/community-living-ontario-applauds-new-budget-increases-for-people-who-have-an-intellectual-disability-and-their-families"><strong>http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1338173/community-living-ontario-applauds-new-budget-increases-for-people-who-have-an-intellectual-disability-and-their-families</strong></a><strong>- April 11, 2014</strong></li>
</ol>
<strong> </strong>
<ol start="2">
	<li><a href="http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1318225/community-living-ontario-thanks-provincial-legislature-s-select-committee-on-developmental-services-for-thoughtful-review-in-newly-released-interim-re"><strong>http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1318225/community-living-ontario-thanks-provincial-legislature-s-select-committee-on-developmental-services-for-thoughtful-review-in-newly-released-interim-re</strong></a><strong>- March 6, 2014</strong></li>
</ol>
<strong> </strong>
<ol start="3">
	<li><a href="http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1312139/in-celebration-of-national-inclusive-education%20month-community-living-ontario-proudly-announces-together-we-re-better-contest-winners"><strong>http://www.newswire.ca/en/story/1312139/in-celebration-of-national-inclusive-education month-community-living-ontario-proudly-announces-together-we-re-better-contest-winners</strong></a><strong>- February 25, 2014</strong></li>
</ol>
<strong>Community Development </strong>

<strong> </strong>

<strong>The intent of the work done through our Community Development department is to design, facilitate, strengthen and build capacity in individuals, families, community groups and our local associations to build inclusive and welcoming communities, where we all belong.</strong>

<strong> </strong>

<strong>The last few months our activity and efforts have focused on:</strong>

<strong> </strong>

1)      <strong>Supporting the Council to build their capacity as a strong advisory body to the Community Living Ontario Board of Directors.  </strong>They have developed a new and more accessible election process, bylaws and protocols that address quorum, absenteeism, the relationship with the Board Liaison and the terms of the Council Appointee to the Board of Directors of Community Living Ontario.  The Council has also updated its local self-advocacy group data base, and is in the process of updating its orientation binder.  The Council is also expanding its networks and participated in forums such as the People First of Ontario conference, engaged in conversation with the “Freedom from Harm” working group and attended ODSP policy meetings.

2)      <strong>Supports to students thinking about graduation and what’s next</strong>.  Supporting students, their families and educators to explore new possibilities through the Passport Mentoring initiative. A summer newsletter recently available captures the stories of students trying new paths and looking at possible employment for the future including construction, working in a movie theatre and owning a landscaping company.  We were able to match 82 students with mentors in the last few months of school this year.

<strong> </strong>

3)      <strong>Supporting young leader’s mobilizing for change</strong>. Our youth leadership group have been actively planning the 6th annual Re: Action4Inclusion Youth Conference.  They have been working on the program that will engage youth in learning about collective and creative advocacy, self-determination and community development.  They work together to understand the principles of a civil society and what they can do to affect change with and on behalf of their peers.  We have also supported the youth to engage Michelle Dagnino (youth consultant) to work on a new project with them “Mobilizing Youth for Action”.  The last few months have been very busy – presentations at schools, supporting them  to bring the conversation of inclusion into their networks and  their communities, and participating in events such as the ,”Count Me In” – Canada’s biggest youth volunteer run event – promoting volunteerism and youth engagement. Our Re: action4Inc students have engaged many more thru their new twitter handle and Facebook accounts <a href="http://www.facebook.com/reaction4inclusion">www.facebook.com/reaction4inclusion</a> @R4Inclusion.  We continue to support local associations for Community Living with their youth efforts and recently partnered with Community Living York in hosting a brother and sisters retreat. We want to grow this area of work and are excited about the year ahead.

&nbsp;

4)      <strong>Continuing to create space and opportunity for families to grow and learn from one another. </strong> A group of parents who have participated in our family leadership weekends and a core group who we refer to as our Planning team, continue to meet and look at ways to learn from the series we have been hosting and to find ways to deepen the learning and opportunity for others

&nbsp;

5)      <strong>Working with our local associations and our national partner on new initiatives in employment</strong>.  We have hired a Labour Market Development &amp; Partnerships Manager and welcome Elisa Oncel to our team.  Currently the effort is to complete and orientation, needs assessment and then to develop a model and structure for the new Ready Willing and Able employment initiative here in Ontario.

&nbsp;

A busy few months – laying the foundation for an exciting fall and winter ahead.  Stay tuned.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Membership</strong>

&nbsp;

<strong>Connecting with Members </strong>

During the first quarter of this year I visited 15 member organizations.  These visits included making presentations to Board members, attending Annual General Meetings, Anniversary Celebrations and special events and meeting with Executive Directors.

The focus of attention this quarter was visiting with members located in Northern Ontario.  Chris Beesley was able to join me on two separate tours.  We visited Community Living members in the towns and cities of Kenora, Fort Francis, Atikokan, Thunder Bay, Kapuskasing, Cochrane, Iroquois Falls, and Timmons.  I also attended the AGMs at two additional Northern organizations;   Community Living Greater Sudbury and Community Living North Bay. We are planning furthers visits this fall in order to see more of our Northern members

Additional organizations visited over this time period included Community Living members in Grimsby, Lincoln and West Lincoln, Haldimand, St. Catharines, Central Huron and Port Colborne-Wainfleet.  I also attended Regional Executive Directors Meetings and participated in teleconference calls with the Provincial Executive Directors Coordinating Committee, the Monday Morning Labour Calls and the Provincial Network Human Resources Committee.

I also met with a number of our members while attending the OASIS Annual Conference in London.  It was a fantastic event and I was welcomed warmly by the OASIS Board during their Gala Event.

<strong>Event Coordination and Membership Engagement</strong>

Three significant events were planned to encourage community and membership engagement.  Membership assisted with logistics, promotion and hosting of the events:
<ol>
	<li>The Select Committee Interim Report that was attended by over 50 people on site and reached over 50 locations remotely through webcast.</li>
	<li>Day at the Jays was again very successful with over 1000 attendees.</li>
	<li>The Benevon Introductory Session on Sustainable funding that attracted interest on site and through webcast.</li>
</ol>
<strong>Conference 2014</strong>

<em>Together We’re Better </em>

Planning is underway for the 2014 Conference and AGM being held September 24<sup>th</sup> to 27<sup>th</sup> in Richmond Hill and we are anticipating a successful event.  Most encouraging is the level of participation from our membership.  Community Living organizations taking part in sessions include Toronto, Elmira, Windsor, Peterborough, London, South-East Grey, Kenora, Grimsby Lincoln and West Lincoln, York South, Dufferin, Belleville, Prince Edward County and The Mills.

Additional sessions are being coordinated with New Vision Advocates, People First, Avon Maitland District School Board, The Provincial Network on Developmental Services and Community Living Education Ontario, The Council, and The Provincial Executive Director Coordinating Committee.

<strong> </strong>

<strong>Strengthening the Confederation Committee</strong>

Membership has provided staff support to the Strengthening the Confederation Committee (SCC). The SCC has begun reviewing existing committees, subcommittees, and working groups of the Community Living Ontario Board including The Executive, Nominations, Finance, Conference, Awards, Francophone Affairs, By-laws and Resolutions, and the Well Being Committee. Terms of Reference were reviewed and changes made as necessary and approved.  All changes and recommendations will be brought forward to the Community Living Ontario Board and if approved, shared with our members at the upcoming AGM in September.

In addition to the development of Strengthening the Confederation Committee, work continues to take place though its subcommittees including Nominations, Conference, and Awards.  Further work through the SCC will focus on criteria for individual and partnership levels of membership and the development of a work plan.

<strong>Financial Summary </strong>

Year to date results for the first quarter of 2014-15 are positive with net revenue of $571k versus a budget of $564k. The approved annual budget shows net revenue of $30k.

&nbsp;

The significant difference year to date is the assessment fees which are recorded when billed in April, but cover expenses which are spread evenly over the year. In addition we have unbudgeted administration fee of $42k being collected on the MCSS Pilot Project which was not included in the approved budget.

&nbsp;

All department spending is on target for the first quarter. There are no significant changes to approved budgets to be reviewed. The budget includes a salary and benefits for a fundraising position which has not yet been filled. As a result of the estates and bequests received this year, the overall targets in this department have been met.

The overall financial position of Community Living Ontario remains solid with net assets of $1.3 million versus $940k at March 31, 2014.

&nbsp;

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Community Living Ontario&#039;s 61st Annual Conference!</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=115</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 29 Jul 2014 17:32:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=115</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[COMMUNITY LIVING ONTARIO WELCOMES YOU TO THE 61ST ANNUAL CONFERENCE!
The 2014 Community Living Ontario conference will build on our shared vision of a society where everyone belongs, has equality respect and acceptance. As a confederation,<span class="text_exposed_show"> we understand the valuable contributions people make when they are truly present and included in the community and have control over their own lives. Together we’re better!</span>

The conference is being held on September 24 - 27, 2014 at the Sheraton Parkway Toronto North Hotel and Suites in Richmond Hill, Ontario. For room reservations call 1-800-668-0101 and mention Community Living Ontario to get the best rates. <a class="_58cn" style="color: #3b5998" href="https://www.facebook.com/hashtag/2gether2014">#2Gether2014</a>

Please visit our digital flyer for registration and program information: <a title="CLO Digital Flyer" href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/2gether2014/">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/2gether2014/</a>

<a title="Conference Digital Flyer" href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/2gether2014/"><img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-116" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/conferencephoto.jpg" alt="conferencephoto" width="571" height="516" /></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>115</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-07-29 17:32:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

		<wp:post_name>community-living-ontarios-61st-annual-conference</wp:post_name>

	<item>
				<title>UPDATE FRIDAY ‘Week in Review’</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=133</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 31 Oct 2014 20:14:36 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[Chris Beesley]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=133</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="color: #000000;">

<strong>The Week in Review</strong>

I hope you all got your<strong> “Employment &amp; Modernization” proposals</strong> in by last Friday’s deadline.  We were pleased to support and partner with several of you.

Many thanks to <strong>Community Living Iroquois Falls, Kirkland Lake, Temiskaming South, Timmins</strong> and the<strong> Cochrane Temiskaming Resource Centre</strong>, for hosting <strong>Keith Dee and I</strong> and engaging in a great discussion of the issues.

Thanks also to the group from the<strong> ‘near north’ – Parry Sound, West Nipissing, North Bay, Almaguin Highlands, Huntsville, Mattawa </strong>and<strong> Muskoka South</strong> for allowing <strong>Kismet Baun and I</strong> to come and present on<strong> ‘Marketing Supports and Services in the World of Individualized Funding’.</strong>

It’s also been a challenging week.  The Ministry has told us that of the $200 million in wage funding for front-line staff, only $80 million will be annualized.  In conjunction with our Provincial Network partners, we will continue to seek clarification on this, as well as the rest of the $810 million funding envelope announced in the provincial budget.

<strong>Finally, please watch out for all the little ghosts and goblins prowling your neighbourhood tonight – </strong><strong>Happy Halloween!</strong>

<a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?C=V4oN0RW_qEaheXQFLqYFTtX2gfauyNEIdumXuNVaOV76Sd42sQLh1qXC5GXM61OxtH5IJfOzDpI.&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-cethlt-ityujttrty-t%2f"><strong>Chris Beesley</strong></a><strong>
Chief Executive Officer
Chef de la Direction
Community Living Ontario
240 Duncan Mill Road, Suite 403
Toronto, Ontario M3B 3S6
(416) 447- 4348, Ext 227
</strong><a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?C=V4oN0RW_qEaheXQFLqYFTtX2gfauyNEIdumXuNVaOV76Sd42sQLh1qXC5GXM61OxtH5IJfOzDpI.&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-cethlt-ityujttrty-h%2f"><strong>communitylivingontario.ca</strong></a>

&nbsp;

</div>
<div style="color: #000000;"></div>
<div style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-80" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Chris_B2.jpg" alt="image of Chris Beesley" width="339" height="339" /></div>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>

	<item>
				<title>What did you want to be when you grew up?</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=136</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 20 Nov 2014 17:06:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=136</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Luca thought he would never get to experience the taste of success.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">He wasn’t encouraged to dream about his future because Luca has an intellectual disability.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">As a high school student, Luca felt he had no options for his future. When asked how he felt about college, Luca says, “I never thought about it. I thought I couldn’t go.”</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Like close to one million Canadian’s with an intellectual disability, Luca was discriminated against. Luca and other people with intellectual disabilities are still excluded from everyday life, segregated into special classrooms, treated with awkwardness, fast-tracked onto social assistance, and placed without choice into living facilities.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><img class="alignright" src="https://gallery.mailchimp.com/e9d05ec81998485ad5e92e7c8/images/e6532456-fcf6-4280-bf4b-c88f2871732a.jpg" alt="" /></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">But this December 2</span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><sup>nd</sup></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">, as part of GivingTuesday, </span><a href="http://givingtuesday.ca/partner-profile-2014/?id=2540#.VG4YHfnF9Oz" target="_blank"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b><span style="color: red">you can help by making a donation </span></b></span></a><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">to </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Community Living Ontario</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">. Your support will help end the exclusion of people with intellectual disabilities like Luca. Following Black Friday and Cyber Monday, </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>GivingTuesday</b></span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">offers a chance to give back, build community and better lives.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>More than 74% of adults with intellectual disabilities are excluded from employment</b></span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">not because they can’t work but because they aren’t given a chance.</span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small">   </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">As Luca now knows.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">In high school, Luca became involved with Community Living’s </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Ready, Willing, &amp; Able</b></span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">program for inclusive employment and worked with his provincial Community Living association to explore his interests and make a career plan. Cooking was at the top of Luca’s list. “I always liked cooking with my sister. We make desserts and I am really good at it.” So…Luca started with a co-op placement in a local restaurant.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">On his first day, he was so nervous he wouldn’t even touch the stove.</span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small">  </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Now, three years later Luca is about to graduate from the Culinary Arts Program at a local community college. </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Recently, Luca’s new found confidence inspired him to compete in national competition. He placed 4</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b><sup>th</sup></b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b> overall, beating out his classmates and other certified chefs.</b></span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Community Living Ontario has a plan to start closing the employment gap for people with intellectual disabilities—because as you know well, a career can mean so much more than just a pay cheque to balance the monthly budget. Through work you meet new friends, you find purpose and meaning, you gain a sense of belonging…of contributing, and a sense of achievement and self-worth.  Just like Luca!</span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small">   </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Now, Luca gives back to his community through his cooking and he’s proud of the work he does. “I’m going to keep cooking for people. I want to cook in a restaurant and make people good food.”</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Today, </span><a href="http://givingtuesday.ca/partner-profile-2014/?id=2540#.VG4YHfnF9Oz" target="_blank"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><span style="color: red"><b>YOU can give back</b></span><span style="color: #333333"> </span></span></a><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">to your community. </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>This December 2</b></span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b><sup>nd</sup></b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">, as part of </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>GivingTuesday</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">, your donation to Community Living Ontario will help more than ever.  The </span><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Ready, Willing, &amp; Able </b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">program is creating jobs in our communites; please help us reach new employers now with a donation this December.</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Are you ready, willing and able to get involved?</b></span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif;font-size: small"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><a href="http://givingtuesday.ca/partner-profile-2014/?id=2540#.VG4YHfnF9Oz" target="_blank"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b><span style="color: red">YOUR gift of just $10 or $25 </span></b></span></a><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">will make a difference, helping Community Living Ontario change the employment landscape. By making a gift to the Community Living Ontario today you can help give more young people just like Luca, a chance!</span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> </span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><a href="http://givingtuesday.ca/partner-profile-2014/?id=2540#.VG4YHfnF9Oz" target="_blank"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b><span style="color: red">Give today and help </span></b></span></a><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>connect people with intellectual disabilities who can and want to work, with real jobs for real pay.</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> Then share your story and gift with your friends and loved ones!</span></span></div>
<ul style="color: #000000">
	<li><span style="color: #333333;font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Share this message on your Facebook or Twitter page, asking </span><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>“What did you want to be when you grow up?”</b></span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #333333;font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Forward this information to your network of family, friends, neighbours and colleagues!  Add a personal note about why inclusive employment is important to you!</span></span></li>
	<li><span style="color: #333333;font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif">Have another idea? Spread the word that inclusive employment works, and get others involved today!</span></span></li>
</ul>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: red;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>*Are you interested in receiving information from Community Living on a regular basis? Then why not subscribe to UPDATE FRIDAY:</b></span></span></div>
<div style="color: #000000"></div>
<div style="color: #000000"><span style="font-family: 'Times New Roman', serif;font-size: medium"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>UPDATE FRIDAY</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> is a newsletter published by</span><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b> Community Living</b></span></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>Ontario </b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">every Friday.</span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">
To </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>SUBSCRIBE</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> to </span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"><b>UPDATE FRIDAY</b></span><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif"> please visit our website at </span><a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?C=B35UhhBfAEOJu9m3-bdTCLTJhkZo2NEIvielgjc7u2qkgA2VgqeO9diWQ4ADic8PPvZ-ELUQBgY.&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2fcommunitylivingontario.ca%2fnode%2f1698" target="_blank"><span style="font-family: Arial, sans-serif">http://communitylivingontario.ca/node/1698</span></a><span style="color: #333333;font-family: Arial, sans-serif">  and click on the subscribe button.</span></span></div>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Big changes are coming to ODSP employment benefits in 2015!</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=139</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 16 Dec 2014 20:22:06 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=139</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<div style="color: #000000; padding-left: 90px;"><a href="http://yourlegalrights.on.ca/sites/all/files/webinar_files/Changes%20to%20employment%20benefits%20-%20ISAC%20Coalition%20Webinar%20-%20Dec%2011%202014%20-%202.pdf"><img class="alignnone  wp-image-80" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Chris_B2-300x300.jpg" alt="image of Chris Beesley" width="385" height="385" /></a></div>
<div style="color: #000000;">

<strong>Hello Everyone,</strong>

For those of you who may have missed the recent webinar that was offered by ISAC and the ODSP Action Coalition they have posted the presentation slides online. <a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=Ub532Yw0eRfDiUqg73PCGIaWY45X6hlGPZnfHd0n6HE-WWnAg-fRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagB0AGoAZAAtAGkAaQBoAGsAaAB5AHkAaAB1AGkALQB1AC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljtjd-iihkhyyhui-u%2f"><strong> </strong></a><a href="http://yourlegalrights.on.ca/sites/all/files/webinar_files/Changes%20to%20employment%20benefits%20-%20ISAC%20Coalition%20Webinar%20-%20Dec%2011%202014%20-%202.pdf"><strong>You can view the slides here.</strong><strong> </strong></a>

As you know, the Ontario government announced in the 2014 budget that they are making changes to employment-related benefits provided through ODSP and OW. <strong>As part of these changes, they are eliminating the</strong> <strong>$100 Work-Related Benefit that people on ODSP currently receive, if they are working</strong>

The Work-Related Benefit is given to both people with disabilities on ODSP and members of their family. It provides $100 per month to each person in an ODSP family who has earnings from a job or a training program, or net earnings from self-employment. It is a mandatory benefit that people receive automatically without needing to apply.

As of April 1, 2015<strong>,</strong> working non-disabled family members of people on ODSP will stop receiving the benefit. People with disabilities on ODSP will stop receiving it as of October 1, 2015.

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/?sm=KZI0NJbqgBoIXOHy5rSHAQ%3d%3d"><strong>The ODSP Action Coalition has created a questionnaire and wants to hear from people on ODSP who are working and who receive the Work-Related Benefit.  </strong></a>

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/?sm=KZI0NJbqgBoIXOHy5rSHAQ%3d%3d"><strong>NOTE: </strong></a><strong>Please complete the questionnaire by January 30, 2015</strong><a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=O5kKGM-tPH-PFHhnXkHif9YbvDGuwekADKLdFH_ZoBz1SJndgOfRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagB0AGoAZAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQBuAC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljtjd-ijdrtyiyuh-n%2f"><strong>. </strong></a><a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/?sm=KZI0NJbqgBoIXOHy5rSHAQ%3d%3d"><strong> </strong><strong>You can access the survey questionnaire here.</strong></a>

Results from the questionnaire will be used to lobby the government about the impact of making this cut and to explain why this is the wrong move.  For more information about the Work-Related Benefit and the changes that are being made to ODSP employment benefits, please see the following resources:

<strong>Webinar: </strong><strong> </strong><strong><a href="http://yourlegalrights.on.ca/webinar/odsp-employment-benefits">click here</a></strong>

<strong>ODSP Action Coalition position paper: </strong> <strong><a href="http://www.odspaction.ca/page/resources-advocacy">click here</a></strong>

<strong>ISAC issue backgrounder</strong>:   <strong><a href="http://www.incomesecurity.org/ODSPEmploymentBenefitsarechangingin2015.htm">click here</a></strong>

<strong><a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=U3nRjoxYy17YmLnDM0-lUJHJ8qkirOpCAlN1TnQHbjz1SJndgOfRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagB0AGoAZAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQBxAC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljtjd-ijdrtyiyuh-q%2f">Chris Beesley,</a></strong>

<a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=U3nRjoxYy17YmLnDM0-lUJHJ8qkirOpCAlN1TnQHbjz1SJndgOfRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagB0AGoAZAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQBxAC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljtjd-ijdrtyiyuh-q%2f"><strong>CEO, Community Living Ontario</strong></a>

&nbsp;

</div>]]></content:encoded>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Do they not think if they take away this incentive that people on disability are going to want to work?? I think the $100 is an incentive for those who are truly trying. But hey who cares, the government thinks it their pocket is better with that money any way! I seriously think they should crack down on the people who gamble, smoke, and drink, not the ones who are really trying to make ends meet!!]]></wp:comment_content>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[As you make these decisions, it's apparent where you stand on compassion, visioning about the future of "marginalized" communities (no matter how it happens -- thru an act of nature, an accident, systemic design)....  
It's clear that social housing and social assistance will always be lacking.  It's clear that public funds will continue to be mismanaged, and go missing, without explanation.  There is more "awareness" about the cuts then there was for the "consultations"....  I got sicker trying to work for so little.  The clawbacks, and the impossible attempts to get employment supports leave me in a worse situation that I could have imagined. I thought that working would improve my self esteem, my quality of life, and my health.  No so, whilst working, I was never able to get the supports I needed to improve my health.]]></wp:comment_content>

	<item>
				<title>Communique: Class Actions Claims Update</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=153</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 16 Dec 2014 20:43:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=153</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="padding-left: 30px"><img src="http://i1.cmail2.com/ei/r/33/EEB/E58/csimport/huronia_jpg_size_xxlarge_letterbox.194316.jpg" alt="" /></p>
<strong>Hello Everyone,</strong>

I want to share with you some important information that I recently received from <a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=gchQX5Kf-IOn0wV18BBOtgMidgci_Y5RamXnBcxC8-tIOAXAg-fRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagBrAHQAbAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQBpAC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljktl-ijdrtyiyuh-i%2f"><strong>Jim and Marilyn Dolmage</strong></a> regarding the number of <strong>Class Action Claims </strong>submitted (figures as of December 8, 2014). They are:
<ul>
	<li><strong>Huronia Regional Centre</strong><strong> </strong>- <strong>1,723</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Rideau Regional Centre</strong> - <strong>1,095</strong></li>
	<li><strong>Southwestern Regional Centre</strong> -<strong> </strong><strong>678</strong></li>
</ul>
"This is an excellent result recognizing both the difficulty in finding and informing people. It appears to be about <strong>40%</strong> of the total class action members. The original goal for Huronia was at least 1,000 claims, so we are well past that figure," says Jim Dolmage.

"Credit is due, in large part to the lawyers for putting in place a well funded campaign. As well, the amount of free publicity through News Channels played a large role in making people aware. As well, your personal interest Chris and the involvement of <strong>Community Living Ontario</strong> to inform and encourage agencies played a major role. I know that your funding for Marie, Patricia, Marilyn and myself to travel and present also increased the claims numbers."

<strong>"Eighty per cent of all claims fall into the B category</strong> of more serious abuse. There continue to be a significant number of contested/incomplete claims and we will receive more information about resolutions in the near future. We'll keep you informed and appreciate the work that <a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=LDK02L_8Hbhdbwh9f3n-DiPtonqU-wh-GrbKDJel8W1IOAXAg-fRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagBrAHQAbAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQBrAC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljktl-ijdrtyiyuh-k%2f"><strong>Brendon Pooran</strong></a> has done," continues Dolmage.

<a href="https://mail.communitylivingontario.ca/owa/redir.aspx?SURL=mFFpBVfF3LsSVY71NHUuY8Pux2OP7WpYsddrY-K8EHGXmgfAg-fRCGgAdAB0AHAAOgAvAC8AZQBiAGwAYQBzAHQALgBnAG8AdABlAG4AegBpAG4AZwAuAGMAbwBtAC8AdAAvAHIALQBsAC0AYwBoAGwAagBrAHQAbAAtAGkAagBkAHIAdAB5AGkAeQB1AGgALQB1AC8A&amp;URL=http%3a%2f%2feblast.gotenzing.com%2ft%2fr-l-chljktl-ijdrtyiyuh-u%2f"><strong>Chris Beesley</strong><strong>
</strong><strong>CEO, Community Living Ontario</strong></a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>153</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2014-12-16 20:43:08</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>communique-class-actions-claims-update</wp:post_name>

		<category domain="category" nicename="communique"><![CDATA[Communique]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[To me it seems that the number of applicants for compensation related to Southwestern Regional Centre is low. Some Community Living agencies supported all eligible people to make a claim but my experience with friends suggests that some did not. It's not fair. Is anyone tracking the responses of specific Associations in terms of number of possible applicants vs number who actually were able to apply? And asking why?]]></wp:comment_content>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>New Year&#039;s Message from the CEO</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=163</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 09 Jan 2015 15:30:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[JdePass]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=163</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Chris_B2.jpg"><img class="alignleft wp-image-80 size-medium" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Chris_B2-300x300.jpg" alt="image of Chris Beesley" width="300" height="300" /></a>

<strong>Happy New Year!</strong> ... I hope 2015 has started off well for you.

As we begin a new year on the calendar, I want to take the opportunity to share with you, a few brief thoughts for 2015: a New Year’s Resolution of sorts.

For the first and hopefully last time in my life, I’m going to quote George W. Bush. In a speech to the NAACP, he once referred to “the soft bigotry of low expectations”. To me, this describes where we are at in 2015, with respect to societal attitudes towards people with an intellectual disability. Prejudice may not be as overt as it once was; it may have gone “soft”, but it is still pervasive.

If we are to change these attitudes, we must promote the notion of “presumed competence”. Presume that everyone has abilities, skills and gifts to share. Presume that we each want to share our unique abilities, skills and gifts and presume that we all need support to be our best and to reach our potential.<!--more-->

Every year, each of us in the Community Living movement must renew our resolve to move the yard stick forward in the areas of community living that most affect our daily lives: where we live, where we go to school, what employment opportunities are available, and what opportunities exist to build friendships. By working together in these areas, we will make steady progress towards true inclusion.

Most New Year’s Resolutions are doomed to fail very shortly after they’ve been made. I believe most would have a much better chance of being successful if they were re-cast as ‘New Day Resolutions'. A whole year seems daunting and too much to tackle. So let’s take each day as a new chance to be successful in making small inroads towards inclusion. Together, we will turn 365 ‘New Day Resolutions' into an amazing year.

On behalf of our Board and our incredible staff, I thank you for your continued partnership and support.

<a href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-ckhuyjt-l-h/"><strong>Chris Beesley, CEO, Community Living Ontario</strong></a>

&nbsp;]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>163</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-01-09 10:30:21</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-01-09 15:30:21</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>new-years-message-from-the-ceo</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
