			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[Miks te niii kahepalgelist pliiitokat teete? Venelastele fcks jutt ja eestlastele hoopis teine. Kuigi mf5lemad on Eesti kodanikud (jah kodanikud, sest kes tahab Eestiga oma saatuse siduda, siis saab ka fche Euroopa lihtsama   Eesti kodakondsuseksami tehtud!). See on sulaselge diskrimineerimine rahvuse pf5hjal ja vaenu f5huamine!]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>trash</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>
			<wp:comment_user_id>0</wp:comment_user_id>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_result</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[false]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1448289378.9904611110687255859375;s:7:"message";s:28:"Akismet cleared this comment";s:5:"event";s:9:"check-ham";s:4:"user";s:0:"";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>akismet_history</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[a:4:{s:4:"time";d:1448293634.718820095062255859375;s:7:"message";s:45:"CLO-admin changed the comment status to trash";s:5:"event";s:12:"status-trash";s:4:"user";s:9:"CLO-admin";}]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_status</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[0]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
			<wp:commentmeta>
				<wp:meta_key>_wp_trash_meta_time</wp:meta_key>
				<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[1448293634]]></wp:meta_value>
			</wp:commentmeta>
		</wp:comment>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Push is on to Make Accessibility a Federal Election Issue</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=430</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 16 Sep 2015 18:36:57 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=430</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;">
<img class="aligncenter wp-image-431 size-full" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/09/uf4.034837.jpg" alt="uf4.034837" width="506" height="300" />A movement is underway to make a Canadians with Disabilities Act a priority in the 2015 federal election.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The Canadian Association for Community Living, Community Living Ontario and other provincial and territorial associations have made the topic part of a five-point plan that speaks to an inclusive labour market, economic opportunity, income security and community access for Canadians with disabilities and their families. This includes the creation and adoption of a Canadians with Disabilities Act.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Specifically, the Act would mandate accessibility standards in federally-regulated programs, facilities, benefits, communications and services. This legislation would be based on principles of universal design, effective participation, and equality of opportunity, and would be a major step in Canada meeting its obligations under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Standards would be monitored, enforceable, and reported on to Parliament and Canadians every year by the responsible minister.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">To date, the Green Party of Canada is the only party to promise a Canadians with Disabilities Act as part of its platform.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">David Lepofsky, Chair of the AODA Alliance and disability accessibility advocate, says a Canadians with Disabilities Act is needed because some of the barriers people with disabilities face can only be regulated by the Canadian government, such as access to federal agencies like Canada Post and Revenue Canada. A number of other services and workplaces need to be regulated federally, including air travel, telecommunications and banking.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“We need to ensure full accessibility and we need the federal government to act.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The Ontario legislature unanimously adopted the Ontarians with Disabilities Act on October 29, 1998, thanks to a campaign led by Lepofsky and supported by Community Living Ontario, among others. A similar Act became law in Manitoba in 2013. Legislation is also being considered in Nova Scotia and British Columbia.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Lepofsky notes that the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms and the Canadian Human Rights Act ensure equality for people with disabilities, but in order to enforce those rights, people must sue.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“In Ontario, when I, as a blind person, wanted bus drivers to announce all bus stops, I had to sue the TTC personally.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">A Canadians with Disabilities Act, according to Lepofsky, could also ensure that federal dollars used on infrastructure and to buy goods and services couldn’t be used to create barriers against people with disabilities. Voluntary provincial standards could also be created to address barriers in areas such as education and health care, and provinces could then adopt them without having to create their own legislation.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">In addition to being Chair of the AODA Alliance, Lepofsky sits on the Steering Committee for Barrier-Free Canada, a non-partisan group also calling for the adoption of a Canadians with Disabilities Act.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The group has developed 14 principles based on those adopted in Ontario and Manitoba, and they cover all disabilities, barriers and how they can be effectively enforced.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Barrier-Free Canada has been busy reaching out to the parties and their candidates through social media, and Lepofsky says they’re encouraging people in the disabilities community to do the same.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“This is a very close election and it’s a long election campaign, so there’s time. Each of the parties knows that every vote counts, so people with disabilities, their families, their friends and people who care about them need to raise this [issue] with candidates at the door.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Barrier-Free Canada has developed an election action kit, which is available on their <a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-fhykhyd-l-n/" target="_blank">website</a>. They have also started a conversation on Twitter using the hashtag #CanadiansWithDisabilitiesAct.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">As mentioned above, the Canadian Association for Community Living, Community Living Ontario and other provincial and territorial associations have committed to raising awareness about the barriers people face, with the development of a five-point plan for the 2015 federal election. For more information on the plan and how to become engaged, visit <a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-fhykhyd-l-p/" target="_blank">www.inclusionmatters.ca</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>430</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-09-16 14:36:57</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-09-16 18:36:57</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>push-is-on-to-make-accessibility-a-federal-election-issue</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="advocacy"><![CDATA[Advocacy]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="general"><![CDATA[General]]></category>
		<category domain="category" nicename="update-friday"><![CDATA[Update Friday]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Toronto-area group committed to finding different housing options for people</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=436</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Oct 2015 17:07:17 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=436</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;">A group of parents from the Scarborough area remains dedicated to finding housing alternatives for their adult children, and their efforts continue to grow in scope and reach.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">When <strong>Scarborough Residential Alternatives</strong> (SRA) began in 2006, there were six families looking for something different than the traditional group home model.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Bonnie Heath</strong>, one of the group’s founders, says Scarborough Residential Alternatives offers parents information on housing, along with encouragement and opportunities to network. They also rely on each other to come up with innovative ideas for alternative living arrangements for their sons and daughters.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft" src="http://i1.createsend1.com/ei/r/23/39E/3B7/csimport/bonie.113910.jpg" alt="" width="293" height="139" />For Heath, a group home was not an option for her daughter, <strong>Jenny</strong>.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“I wanted something different that she had control of and that was more a part of the community.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">According to Heath, the families wanted to find alternative housing for their children, but didn’t want to wait until they were in their 90s to do so. Jenny has been living on her own for the past six years.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“She has a roommate and they have a live in, and she’s just part of the community. When she talks about home it’s her home, it’s not mine anymore. It’s been a total learning experience for her and her roommate, as well as for us, as parents,” says Heath.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Her daughter lives in a townhouse that’s part of a larger complex. When they first moved in, they held an open house for other tenants in the complex so that they could meet their new neighbours. Barbecues and other events have also been organized since their arrival.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Heath says she has seen tremendous personal growth in her daughter since Jenny found a place of her own.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“She would never have had that growth if she continued to live with me. It’s a hard sell to parents because we’re all over protective, but it’s also allowed me to get my life back. We’re still closely connected, but we still have our own separate lives.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">There are eight homes leased by people who have ties with SRA. The types of housing range from condos and townhomes to apartments and houses located in neighbourhoods across the city, not just Scarborough.Today, about 120 families are involved with SRA, and they stay in touch mostly through email.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The group submitted an innovative housing proposal earlier this year, as part of the <strong>Ministry of Community and Social Services’</strong><em>Developmental Services Housing Task Force</em>. It was turned down, but they intend to re-apply.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Heath is a member of the Housing Task Force, although she was not part of the Selection Committee that chose the 12 pilot projects that will receive funding.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“We had 80 organizations submit proposals. There’s a huge need and something has to be done that’s different than the way [the Ministry] does it now. Hopefully, the money should be starting to roll out to this first set of projects. From there, we’ll be able to see, over time, how well they work out. The objective of course is to see it work in other areas.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Heath is a strong supporter of individualized funding for residential supports so that people can live where they want and choose how they want to live their lives. However, she is not in favour of people with intellectual disabilities living together in large group homes.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Originally, we had tried to get a floor of a building where they could all live. It wasn’t a group home, but it was the same sort of idea. Our proposal wasn’t accepted and, looking back, it was a good thing that is wasn’t because it’s much better the way we’ve done it.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Heath says she can appreciate why some families may want to push for a group home. However, she thinks having a large number of people living together is problematic and she’s in favour of people living in the community.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“There’s safety in the community, which people don’t seem to think there is. They all think it’s safer for their kids to be in a group home situation. But in the community where Jenny lives, the community looks out for her. I can appreciate why everyone looks at a group home, because it’s less expensive. But to live with 18 people, that’s a lot of people to live with.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">SRA has also developed a guide to assist parents with accessing funding and community supports to enable their sons and daughters to transition into homes of their own.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“I thought let’s make it a simple guide that’s got the Ministry’s web site. It also talks about ODSP and how you get the rent portion. A lot people don’t realize that when you rent somewhere, you receive a couple hundred dollars, approximately. It talks about your Passport dollars and what you can use it for, as well as person-directed planning and independent facilitation – a lot people get the plans done, but they don’t know how to implement the goals.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The guide is available for download by accessing Scarborough Residential Services’ <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zykthdk-l-k/" target="_blank">web site</a></strong>. Families can post ads on the web site for roommates that fit the criteria they’re looking for. SRA will also post notices for support workers.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche</strong></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

			<wp:comment_id>18643</wp:comment_id>
			<wp:comment_author><![CDATA[Jorgel]]></wp:comment_author>
			<wp:comment_author_email>5e68k19bk@gmail.com</wp:comment_author_email>
			<wp:comment_author_url>http://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100003469648608</wp:comment_author_url>
			<wp:comment_author_IP>221.178.182.12</wp:comment_author_IP>
			<wp:comment_date>2015-11-23 09:19:59</wp:comment_date>
			<wp:comment_date_gmt>2015-11-23 14:19:59</wp:comment_date_gmt>
			<wp:comment_content><![CDATA[என ன எல ல ர ம  அந த ப ண ணப  ப ட ட  வ ங க ற ங க?., வ ள ந ட ட  வ ல ய ல இர க க ன ன  என ன  பந த ப  பண ண ற ங க?., நம ம ள க எங க ய ய  தர ய ல நடக க ற ய ங க?., ம தப ப லல ல த ர ய ற ய ங க?. எல ல ம  ந ங க வ ட ற பந த வப  ப த த  ப ர ச  ந ன ச ச க க றத த ன . அம ர க க  வர றத க க  ம ன ன ந ய ஜ ர ச  இப பட , ந ய ய ர க  இப பட ன ன  ஒர  அளவத ன  நம ம நண பர  க ட டத த க க ட ட இர ந த ., ஆன  ந ன  எப பவ ம  லவ க க ச ற ற ப  ப ண ட அல ச சல  வ ழ வ ல ர ந த  வ ட தல  (அட., ப ன  நவ னத த வம  வ ள ய ட த ) அடந த  வ ட டத த ன ல  எத ய ம  ப ர ச  எட த த க கல ., வந த  ப த த த ன  த ர ய த  ந ய ஜ ர ஸ  அப ப ர ட ம ண ட  வ ட கள ல  இர க க ற ப ச ச த  த ல ல உலகத த ல எந த ஊர லய ம  இர க க த . எல ல த த ய ம  ச கண ட  ஹ ண ட ல வ ங க ட ட  இந தப  பசங க வ ட ற பந த ....(கவன க கவ ம ., இத  ந ன  க ற ய கச  ச ல லவ ல ல .)ந ங க உர வ க க  வ த த ர க க ற ப ம பம  தவற னத . அத  எத ர  க ள ள ம  ப ண ண ன  அத ர ச ச ய  ஏன  க ற  ச ல க ற ர கள ?. வ ங க க ற சம பளத த வர றவக க ட ட ச ல ற... ஆன  க ர ட ட  க ர ட ல ந  வ ங க ய ர க க ற கடன ச  ச ல ல  இர க க ற ய ?., ஒர  ப ள ள., அத  நல ல  ச க கப ப ர ல வ ள  ப ர த த  ந ம மத ய  வ ழ க க ய ஓட ட ட ட  இர ந த த ., இங க ய ர ந த  ப ன ர  நம ம ம னர ., த ர மணம  ச ய த  க ட ட ட ட  வந த ., (சம பளம  60 K ந ன  ச ல ல ய ர க க ற ர ., ட க ஸ  ப ட க க றத எல ல ம  ச ல லல., ப த த ம  ப த வ  60) நண பர கள க க  ப ர ட ட  வ த த  ப ண ண அசத த ., ம த வ  ச ல ய ர க க ற ர .,  "இங க ப ர  ட ர ல ங .... வ ட ட  ல ன ,  (அவர  அவ ங க அம ம  அப ப வ க க  கட ட க  க ட த தத ).நம ம த ர மணத த க க  ச லவ  ச ஞ சத  (ப ர ம  ப ண ண  வ ட ட ல பண ண ய ர க க ங க), க ர  ல ன ., க ரட ட  க ர ட  ல ன  இப ப ட க  'க ஞ சம ' கம ட ம ண ட ஸ  இர க க . ம சம  200$ த ன  வ ட ட க க  ச லவ க க  தர ம ட ய ம ன  'ஆட டம  ப ம' அச ல ட ட  த க க  ப ட., ப ண ண  அழ த க க ட ட  நம ம வ ட ட க க  வந தத ., அப ப றம  என ன? இப ப சம யல த ள க க றத  மட ட ம த ன  அந தப  ப ண ண  வ ல ., மத தத  எல ல ம  தம ப த ன . அப ப ண  வ ல  ப ர த த க  க ண ட ர க க றத . மற ற ர  ப ண ண 'வ ப ' க ம ர வ ல  மட ட ம  ப ர த த  கரம  பற ற ய ர ந த ர  ஒர வர . ப ண ண  வந த  இறங க ன அட த த ந ள ., உன  பல ல  எட ப ப  இர க க  ம த த ரல ம ன  ட ண ட ஸ ட க ட ட க ட ட ட ட ப  ப ய க க ட ட ., எங க ப ன ல ம  கஸ டமர  சர வ ஸ க ட ட அந தப  ப ண ணப  ப ச வ ட ட ., ட ஸ  பண ண ன ன  வ ள ய ண ட  இர க க ர  ம ப ப ள ள . ப ண ண  ப ர த த ச ச ., இவன இப ப ட ய  வ ட ட  சர ப பட த ன ன  டப ப ன ன  தல  ம ட ய வ ட ட ச ச ., ஒர  ட லர  ட ர ல ப ய   வ ல  ப ர த த ச ச ., அட த த ம தம  ஒர  கம ப ன ல HR ல  வ ல க க  ச ர ந த ., "ஏய ., வ ட டத  த ற" ந ன  ச யந தரம  வந தத ம  அவர டம  ச வ யத  த க க ப ப ட த . இப பட ய ல ல ம  தன  க பத த  ஆக கப ப ர வம க க ட டத  த ர ய த ப ண கள  அடக க ம ற ய ல  இறங க க ற ர கள  இதப  பண ண த ., அதப  பண ண த  என ற . நமத  இள ஞர கள ன  ஈட ட ம த றன  எவ வளவ  அத கர த த  வர க றத ., அவ வளவ  தன ம னம ம ., நல ல க ணங கள ம  க ற ந த  க ண ட  வர க றத . வ தன ய டன  இத ச  ச ல க ற ன . ப த த அப பன இங க க ட ட ட ட  வந த  என ன  வ தன ப  பட த த ற ய ங க?. (எல ல ர ய ம  ச ல லல ச ம .)///ஆர சர ட  ச ல ய ல ம , CBD-ய ல ம  ப க ப படம  எட த த  அன ப ப ம  நமத  ம ப ப ள ள  wannabe-கள  ச ங கப ப ர ல  த ங கள  வச க க ம  வ ட ட  (அ) அற ய  க ட ட வத ல ல .///100% சதவ த உண ம ., ந ய ஜ ர ச ல  க ர  ம ல ச ஞ ச  ந ன ன  ப ஸ  க ட த த  படம  அன ப ப ம  ப த  க டவ ., க ஞ சம  அப ப ர ண ட ம ன ட ல  உள ள கரப ப ன ப ச ச ய டன ம  ஒர  ப ட ட  எட த த  உங கள  வர ங க ல மன வ  ஆற ற வ ண ட ய கடம கள கள  க ற ப ப கவ ன ம  உணர த த க கள  சக தரர கள !!!., அந தப  ப ண ண  'ப க ன  ஸ ப ர ய ' எப பட ய வத  க ஞ சம  மற த த  எட த த  வரட ட ம . இங க எத க க ம  ப க த .]]></wp:comment_content>
			<wp:comment_approved>trash</wp:comment_approved>
			<wp:comment_type></wp:comment_type>
			<wp:comment_parent>0</wp:comment_parent>

	<item>
				<title>Omar&#039;s Passion is in Focus</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=449</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2015 14:36:24 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CLO-admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=449</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<strong><span style="font-size: 12pt;">Help students like Omar match their passion with purpose on #GivingTuesday with a donation to Community Living Ontario or support Student Links by becoming a mentor. </span></strong>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">By making a financial commitment to Community Living Ontario, you are assisting youth like Omar Shehadeh. Omar loves taking pictures. That much is evident from his work presented at Community Living Ontario’s 6th Annual COMMENCE Conference this past winter. His photography showcased stunning lakeside sunsets, autumn forests with freshly fallen leaves and towering cityscapes. </span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">Michelle Chappus, his mentor, says “He has a great eye and he’s a natural at taking pictures. He’s always taking pictures.” Sherry, Community Living Ontario’s Student Links Coordinator for the Windsor-Essex Region matched Chappus, a member of the Windsor Camera Club, with Omar. Chappus is a retired teacher who loves photography and working with youth. </span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">“Omar has opened up my eyes to the beauty around me, at times when I may have missed looking outside of the box from my own perspective.” <img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-450" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/Omar-ACWR-002-ed-300x225.jpg" alt="Omar ACWR 002 ed" width="300" height="225" /> </span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">At Chappus’ urging, Omar joined the club and has been involved in three group shows. He’s found his passion for photography to be profitable, and he has started selling his work. As for the future, Omar plans on putting his skills to further use saying, “I probably want to be a wedding photographer.” </span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">A whole new world of possibilities opened up for Omar and for many other youth across Ontario because of the Student Links initiative.  <strong>You too can make a difference</strong> on #GivingTuesday. Your donation will help to support Community Living Ontario’s activities so that young people like Omar can find their passion and develop lasting relationships in their community.</span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;"><strong>Want to become a mentor yourself? For more information, contact: </strong></span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">Joel MacIntyre <a href="mailto:jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca">jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 236</span>

<span style="font-size: 12pt;">Linda White <a href="mailto:lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca">lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 239</span>

<script src="//app.etapestry.com/hosted/eTapestry.com/etapEmbedResponsiveResizing.js" type="text/JavaScript"></script><iframe id="etapIframe" style="border: none; width: 100%;" src="https://app.etapestry.com/onlineforms/CommunityLivingOntario/onlinegiving-1.html" width="300" height="150"></iframe>

<hr />]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
				<title>Jay Patel has some serious aspirations and skills to boot up your next web site!</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=464</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2015 15:21:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CLO-admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=464</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[It’s never too early to start planning for the future. That’s why Jay Patel, 15, hasn’t simply learned web development through Student Links—he’s developed a set of skills that he hopes will have a direct application to the family business. Patel worked with Rohit Prasad, his mentor and a recent graduate of Software Engineering and Industrial Design. Together, the pair designed a web site concept for his father’s metalwork company, D and J Fabrication in North York. Jay developed content and populated the web site. The best part was that the concept was not just an exercise—there are plans to launch the web site as part of his father’s business.

<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Jay-and-Rohit.jpg"><img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-303" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/Jay-and-Rohit-290x300.jpg" alt="Jay and Rohit" width="290" height="300" /></a>Jay’s excitement for learning was evident from the get-go. “Meeting Jay was really exciting because he reminded me of myself when I was in high school,” recalled Rohit. “He loves technology, he’s super eager to learn and he’s willing to try new things. So when we first met, we decided it would be a good idea to learn how to create a simple web site. I’d walk him through it and he could keep exploring other possibilities on his own.”

Jay seems to be doing just that. Not only is he developing the site for D and J Fabrication, he hopes to take over the company himself one day. He’s trained for that potential eventuality, having helped out over the years. “I’ve seen a lot of physical metal work, and I figured I felt strong enough to be able to take over that stuff,” he boasted. “I’ve known how to use a lot of machines. I use the welding machine. I use the punching machine, pretty much everything.”

Rohit gained something from spending time with Jay as well. “It was great being exposed to Jay’s eagerness to learn, but also at the same time, it felt great to impart knowledge, to be able to teach something you’re passionate about, and work with someone equally passionate about it.<strong> </strong>

Since their time together, Rohit has taken a job in Germany, but the positive relationship he developed with Jay has left its mark. “We’re going to keep in touch, and I like to think he’s learned as much from me as I did from the whole experience!”

The opportunity with Student Links has given Jay what he believes is a strong direction to focus on as he completes high school, saying “I’d like to start taking IT courses, business, stuff like that.”

In addition to possibly taking over the family business one day, Jay is exploring the idea of opening his own IT company, which may assist D and J Fabrication as well. Planning for the future, indeed!

A whole new world of possibilities opened up for Jay and for many other youth across Ontario because of the Student Links initiative. <strong>You too can make a difference</strong> on <strong>#GivingTuesday.</strong> Your donation will help to support Community Living Ontario’s activities so that students like Jay can find their passion and develop lasting relationships in their community.

<strong>Want to become a mentor yourself? For more information, contact: </strong>

Joel MacIntyre <a href="mailto:jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca">jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 236

Linda White <a href="mailto:lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca">lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 239

<span style="font-size: 14pt;"><strong>Donate now</strong></span>

<script src="//app.etapestry.com/hosted/eTapestry.com/etapEmbedResponsiveResizing.js" type="text/JavaScript"></script><iframe id="etapIframe" style="border: none; width: 100%;" src="https://app.etapestry.com/onlineforms/CommunityLivingOntario/onlinegiving-1.html" width="300" height="150"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-10-28 15:21:30</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>jay-patel-has-some-serious-aspirations-and-skills-to-boot-up-your-next-web-site</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	<item>
				<title>Reyaz works out the Kinks, Rocks On</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=468</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2015 15:23:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CLO-admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=468</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[No one can tell Reyaz Sulaiman that his options for the future are limited. Through Student Links, Reyaz has had the opportunity to explore and learn from industry professionals in three distinct areas of passion – chiropractic medicine, the music industry, and a recently discovered love of public speaking.

“I was feeling really happy,” Reyaz said, when asked how he reacted to news that Paul, a chiropractor in North York, agreed to take him on as a student. Working with Paul and physiotherapist Chetana, he learned to operate the ultrasound machine, hot wax machine, Tens machine, heating pads and other equipment. He has had the opportunity to shadow assessments and to learn about chiropractic care.

<img class="alignright wp-image-469 size-medium" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/ReyazDJing-4-300x193.jpg" alt="ReyazDJing (4)" width="300" height="193" />Reyaz is also a big fan of calypso and reggae music and especially dancehall rapper, musician and singer, Sean Paul. He submitted his favourite songs as part of his personal curated playlist that MuchMusic aired under his name in March. “I was so excited to see my name on the TV,” Reyaz proclaimed, grinning infectiously from ear to ear.

Far from just a friendly, inclusive gesture, the playlist turned out to be a shrewd business move. Gregg Stewart is Bell Media’s Associate Director of Music Marketing Strategy.

“Sean Paul has never failed to deliver, when it comes to numbers on radio and television, across this country or any country for that matter. It’s a known fact – a statistic, actually – that anything with those kind of vibes and his music, in particular, that it’s definitely an audience draw. When Reyaz sent us some ideas as to what it was he liked, we were all thrilled and excited to work with him to compile that hour of music.”

Asked how she views the positive experiences Reyaz has had, his mother Camille, summed it up succinctly. “Awesome, in one word.” It’s apparent that she has seen some changes in her son since he started getting hands-on experience in the areas he was interested in, saying “I’ve seen so much growth in him. It’s really been awesome. He’s just blossomed into being more responsible and more independent.”

As for future plans, Reyaz has recently discovered a love for public speaking. He is working with Marlon, a member of his local Toastmasters organization, to develop a story of his life. He isn’t quite sure what he’ll do with it, but he loves motivational speaking. “All of my cousins, my uncle,” he said, listing some of his family members who have encouraged him to talk in front of an audience. “I really like to speak in a crowd.”

A whole new world of possibilities opened up for Reyaz and for many other youth across Ontario because of the Student Links initiative. <strong>You too can make a difference</strong> on #GivingTuesday. Your donation will help to support Community Living Ontario’s activities so that students like Reyaz can find their passion and develop lasting relationships in their community.

<hr />

<strong>Want to become a mentor yourself? For more information, contact:</strong>

Joel MacIntyre <a href="mailto:jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca">jmacIntyre@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 236

Linda White <a href="mailto:lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca">lwhite@communitylivingontario.ca</a> (416) 447-4348 ext. 239

<span style="text-decoration: underline;"><strong>Donate Now:</strong></span>

<script src="//app.etapestry.com/hosted/eTapestry.com/etapEmbedResponsiveResizing.js" type="text/JavaScript"></script><iframe id="etapIframe" style="border: none; width: 100%;" src="https://app.etapestry.com/onlineforms/CommunityLivingOntario/onlinegiving-1.html" width="300" height="150"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>468</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-10-28 11:23:47</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-10-28 15:23:47</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>reyaz-works-out-the-kinks-rocks-on</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="giving-tuesday"><![CDATA[Giving Tuesday]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Personal Outcome Measures Changing Lives, Building Community</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=472</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2015 19:01:51 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=472</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;">Nearly a year and a half into their commitment to improve service delivery, <a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-b/"><strong>Community Living Upper Ottawa Valley</strong></a> (CLUOV), staff and people supported continue to reap the benefits of introducing personal outcome measures training.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Thanks to a three-year, $200,000 grant from the Ontario Trillium Foundation, CLUOV and the <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-n/">Madawaska Valley Association for Community Living</a></strong> (MVACL) have been working with staff on a best practice model developed by the Council for Quality and Leadership (CQL).</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Beginning last year, employees at both organizations have been participating in workshops to enhance the lives of people with intellectual disabilities. In the case of CLUOV, that means approximately 100 staff have been receiving training to assist more than 150 people and their families.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">At the end of the three-year timeframe, CLUOV and MVACL will each have an interviewer and two trainers on staff to be able to continue to measure the quality of their service offerings.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The investment ha<img class="alignleft size-medium wp-image-473" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/teamwork.130135-300x177.jpg" alt="teamwork.130135" width="300" height="177" />s meant that CLUOV is positioned to better plan service delivery and increase opportunities for collaboration in the region. As part of their community outreach, CLUOV has met with 25 staff from a long-term care home in the area, as well as a representative from L’Arche.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Tina Williams</strong>, Manager of Quality Enhancement for Community Living Upper Ottawa Valley, says the measures and the training are really about helping people determine their priorities and preferences, which impacts everyone.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“The outcome measures don’t only apply to people with disabilities. There’s a process that can be used with people who have mental health diagnoses and also people who are seniors. [The measures] are relevant to all of our lives. If we look at ourselves and we think about the things that are most important to us, they fit into the 21 personal outcome measures criteria.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Since the introduction of CQL and subsequent interviews with people about their goals and priorities, CLUOV has seen noticeable trends emerge. <strong>Chris Grayson</strong>, Executive Director for Community Living Upper Ottawa Valley, says they realized they hadn’t had much recent success in enabling people to choose where and with whom they wanted to live and where they wanted work.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">As a result, the partners have held a couple of symposiums that brought together about 80 people to look at issues around housing. A similar symposium was held around employment and brought 65 people to the table, including representatives from the local college, school boards, employment service providers, ODSP and Ontario Works.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Grayson feels it’s important to bring organizations together to work on issues of mutual interest, like housing and employment.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“The more you work with less familiar partners, the more integration you have. If we’re working with housing, they might not know much about what we do, but they have a housing mandate. At our symposium last year, we had a developer approach us and he’s just purchased one of our group homes. We’re getting out of the group home business and this gentleman was in the audience. He’s bought the group home and he’s going to convert it to housing, probably for students or nurses.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Grayson referenced another example of a builder that has changed his business model and is now focused exclusively on accessible housing.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“If we can make the community a better place by introducing choice through the outcome measures then, in the long run, I think all of us in the region will be better off.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">As a result of their involvement in the community, CLUOV has been asked to participate in the initiatives of others. The organization took part in the strategic plan of a nearby college, the planning process for the City of Pembroke, and they have had input with the local Accessibility Advisory Committee.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“This has made us a willing partner. We didn’t expect those things at the frontend, but they do happen because people get accustomed to you and our agency is prepared to play with other organizations,” adds Grayson.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">As part of the organization’s strategic plan, he says CLUOV is also taking steps to become fully accredited in 2016 through CQL.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“On any given day, there are stresses, pressures and things that can go wrong. But if you look at those 21 outcome measures and commit to doing your best in all those areas, people’s lives will change for the better.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>472</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-10-28 15:01:51</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-10-28 19:01:51</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>personal-outcome-measures-changing-lives-building-community</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="update-friday"><![CDATA[Update Friday]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Compass Provides Kelly with Employment Opportunity</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=478</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 29 Oct 2015 13:22:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=478</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Kelly Bosshart</strong> likes to work with numbers. In her previous roles as an accounting assistant and office assistant, she handled large sums of money, processed invoices and handled vast amounts of information. When the Brampton woman was looking for a job this past summer prior to enrolling in the Office Administration, Medical program at <strong>Sheridan College</strong>, she was successful in securing a position with <strong>Compass Group Canada</strong>. Based in Mississauga, the company is a leader in food and support services, employing over 26,000 people across the country.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Bosshart was able to make the connection thanks to her previous experience, as well as through her involvement with the <strong>Redpath Centre</strong> and <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-e/">Ready, Willing &amp; Able</a></strong>. A collaboration between the<strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-s/">Canadian Association for Community Living</a></strong>, the <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-g/">Canadian Autism Spectrum Disorders Alliance</a></strong> and partners including Community Living Ontario, Ready, Willing &amp; Able is a national initiative focused on increasing the labour force participation of job seekers with intellectual disabilities or who are on the autism spectrum.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Within a two-week period, Bosshart’s job coach submitted her resume to Ready,<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/compass.144922.jpg"><img class="alignright size-medium wp-image-479" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/10/compass.144922-300x177.jpg" alt="compass.144922" width="300" height="177" /></a> Willing &amp; Able, she was interviewed for the position and Bosshart was hired shortly after. Over the course of the summer, Bosshart worked in the Diversity office, gathering and recording important data, which she enjoyed a great deal.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“You had to know how to manage your time and to make sure that you were getting things done as efficiently and productively as possible. [The workplace] was very conducive to being productive. I didn’t feel any stress or anxiety like, ‘Oh, I’m not going to get this done on time.’”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Gaynor Feltmate</strong> is the Diversity and Inclusion Specialist for Compass Group Canada, and she was also Kelly’s supervisor. In addition to being approachable and hard working, Feltmate says Bosshart was willing to take on any task.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“I was impressed with Kelly’s professionalism and the dedication to her job. Feedback from her co-workers was really positive.”<!--more--></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Feltmate adds that inclusive hiring is part of Compass’ philosophy, and looking at all potential areas of employment is important to accommodate and support their employees so that they realize their potential and contribute to the company’s success.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Working with Ready, Willing &amp; Able has enabled us to tap into a pool of talented and capable individuals that, otherwise, we would not have had access to. We gave them the criteria and job description and they did the rest. They went through their pool of individuals to identify suitable candidates. We anticipate that our continued involvement with Ready, Willing &amp; Able will open the door to more associates being identified and hired to support our business needs.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Once she completes her program, Bosshart hopes to continue to pursue her career in office administration or to seek out a position that would allow her to travel. Looking back, she was very appreciative of the whole experience.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“It was a great opportunity and I really enjoyed working for Compass. I’m grateful that Ready, Willing &amp; Able was able to assist me with getting a summer job. They were incredibly helpful.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">October is National Disability Employment Awareness Month, an occasion to educate the business community about the barriers to employment for people with intellectual disabilities or ASD and to celebrate the gains made in inclusive employment.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Did you know that of the more than 500,000 people with intellectual disabilities or ASD in Canada, only one in four are gainfully employed? Yet, 75% or more of employers rate their workers with intellectual disabilities or ASD as good to very good on most performance indicators. The average turnover rate in Canada for workers across all industries is 49%, and the rate for workers with intellectual disabilities is 7%. There are virtually no exceptional costs to hiring someone with an intellectual disability or ASD.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Become an inclusive employer like Compass Group Canada. Visit Ready, Willing &amp; Able’s <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zjutiz-l-w/">web site</a></strong> to see how you can get started. Better yet, contact a Labour Market Facilitator to learn about Ready, Willing &amp; Able’s hiring process:</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><em>Greater Toronto Area</em>
<strong>Barrington Hector</strong>
416-447-4348 ext. 246
<a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://mailto:bhector@communitylivingontario.ca/">bhector@communitylivingontario.ca </a>

<p style="color: #000000;"><em>Toronto</em>
<strong>Thivjan Tharma</strong>
416-447-4348 ext. 235
<a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://mailto:thivjan@communitylivingontario.ca/">thivjan@communitylivingontario.ca </a>

<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>478</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-10-29 09:22:47</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-10-29 13:22:47</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>compass-provides-kelly-with-employment-opportunity</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>

		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>

			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5]]></wp:meta_value>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Together, One Dream: A Collaborative Approach to Supporting People</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=498</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 02 Nov 2015 19:17:31 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=498</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft" src="http://i2.createsend1.com/ei/r/4C/93B/6B0/csimport/newday.104846.jpg" alt="" width="310" height="184" /></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Earlier this year, we featured a story about <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://communitylivingessex.org/">Community Living Essex County</a></strong> and its relationships with key stakeholders that enable the organization to provide individualized and flexible support to people with intellectual disabilities and their families.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">We recently reconnected with the agency to get an update on their<em>Together, One Dream</em> model and how they’re looking to make it available to others.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Since 2000, Community Living Essex County has partnered with <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://www.ensembleunderstands.com/">Ensemble</a></strong>, a parent-directed resource for families caring for someone with a disability, to make more informed organizational decisions and to enhance support, resources and services to the communities of Essex County.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“When we started, one of the main objectives was to have family leadership consultants who would connect families with families to empower them, and to do it in a way that only families can,” says<strong>Nancy Wallace-Gero</strong>, Executive Director of Community Living Essex County.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“At first, it was ‘Let’s try this out and see how it works.’ But, to be honest, it worked so well that it wasn’t very long after that the Board of Directors was quite prepared to embed this model in the organization in a way that Ensemble’s funding would be seen as part of our annual expenditures and something that was critical to the organization’s success.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">In 2004, <a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://communitylivingessex.org/partners/new-day-leaders-of-today/"><strong>New Day - Leaders of Today</strong></a> was formed, a self-advocacy organization. It too plays a vital role in ensuring that the collective voice of people with intellectual disabilities is represented.<!--more--></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Something was missing with only the family leadership group and the agency itself. You weren’t hearing from the people that were supported, so that’s where New Day came in,” says <strong>Ray Renaud</strong>, a member of the group. “We wanted to know what was going on and how we could help out and have a say”.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Wallace-Gero says that while the family connection is a critical one and brings a great deal of opportunities to families, New Day is the voice of the people that Community Living Essex County supports.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“A lot of New Day’s work is directed towards helping people find their voice, helping people learn how to make decisions and completely control their lives, and helping the agency understand what it really means to provide good support to people.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Marilyn Godard</strong> is a member of Ensemble’s Advisory Committee, and she’s also the parent of an adult daughter with a significant disability. She says New Day not only provides a support to the agency, but the group also provides assistance to her as a parent.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“When I listen to them, I’m learning. ‘Oh, this is the perspective that they have.’ And it helps me get some direction for my own daughter, because she can’t tell me those things.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">As part of their commitment to the Together, One Dream model, Community Living Essex County’s Board of Directors makes funding and support resources available, but each organization, including New Day and Ensemble, has full control over the direction of their own work.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Now, thanks to a generous grant from <strong>Green Shield Canada</strong>, the partners have developed tools that allow them to share the concept and their successes with others. Over the last month, they have presented their model at Community Living Ontario’s annual conference in Hamilton and the Claiming Full Citizenship conference in Vancouver. A video has also been created to highlight the benefits of the partnership.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“People were very touched by the video in Hamilton and Vancouver,” says Godard. “We were asked on numerous occasions how to access the model, would we be willing to do a workshop, and would we be willing to provide training – we got that in both locations.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Wallace-Gero says in addition to using the grant money to create the video and presentation, some of the funding is being allocated for the development of tools and a how-to companion guide that will accompany the video. Other organizations will then be able to access the video and guide as part of a package when developing their own framework.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“It’s a relatively simple model when you look at it, but it isn’t happening everywhere. And we believe there are huge benefits to the partnerships and lessons that we’ve learned along the way that, if we share them with others, could help other communities consider a similar approach.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Godard adds, "We all need to connect and share; agencies providing supports to individuals living with disabilities, families and self-advocates; creative and meaningful supports ensuring lives that maximize potential and access to full citizenship. Together, One Dream.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Check out Community Living Essex County's video - <em>Together, One Dream</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><a href="http://bottledmedia.com/community-living-green-shield/"><img class="alignnone" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/sites/default/files/clessexvideo.gif" alt="Community Living Essex Video Link" width="506" height="240" /></a></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>498</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-11-02 14:17:31</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-11-02 19:17:31</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>together-one-dream-a-collaborative-approach-to-supporting-people</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	<item>
				<title>Webcast Links from Community Living Ontario&#039;s 62nd Annual Conference</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=502</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 04 Nov 2015 16:41:04 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[CLO-admin]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=502</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[In case you missed it, we have included video links from some of the sessions held at this year's Annual Conference.

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>S.T.A.R. - Rights and Abuse Training</b>

Stop Think Act Report (S.T.A.R.) is a program that focuses on rights and abuse training that is presented in an interactive manner. It concentrates on five forms of abuse; Verbal, Physical, Sexual, Financial, and Neglect. They empower the people receiving the training on how to recognize abuse, stand up for themselves, report the abuse and get out of abusive situations. Additionally, they discuss rights and responsibilities and how the two are equally important in everyday life.

The session was run by a team of three self-advocate and two staff mentors from the People Helping People Achieve group. They discussed the five types of abuse and take time focusing on each one and how to respond to abuse. This interactive workshop included games, Q &amp; A, role play, videos and a PowerPoint presentation.

<iframe src="http://livestream.com/accounts/8705923/events/4372566/videos/100803091/player?autoPlay=false&amp;height=360&amp;mute=false&amp;width=480" width="480" height="270" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>

<hr />

&nbsp;

<strong>PEDCC Session - </strong><strong>From Sheltered Programs to Competitive Employment and Building a Full and Rich Life</strong>

This session explored the current state of employment services for people with an intellectual disability and how to create meaningful opportunities to enrich people’s lives beyond their work day. Panelists discussed employment in detail – the opportunities, current strategies to engage employers, the ideal service delivery model, what success looks like and transition strategies in moving from sheltered program models. The session also explored other community-based opportunities that help comprise a full and rich life.

<iframe src="http://livestream.com/accounts/8705923/events/4372566/videos/100815702/player?width=480&amp;height=270&amp;autoPlay=false&amp;mute=false" width="480" height="270" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>

<hr />

&nbsp;

<b>What’s on Your Mind?</b>

In this interactive session, attendees were asked to participate in discussions on priority topics identified by the Council: Bullying and Euthanasia (Assisted Suicide). This session included group brainstorming, sharing of personal views and experiences, debates and concluded with ideas on how to address each issue. Attendees were given the option to join an email list in order to receive updates regarding the progress of the plans and ideas discussed. The Council  also used this opportunity to introduce themselves and relay the importance the role of Council plays within local associations and province wide.

<iframe src="http://livestream.com/accounts/8705923/events/4372566/videos/100823316/player?width=480&amp;height=270&amp;autoPlay=false&amp;mute=false" width="480" height="270" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>502</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-11-04 11:41:04</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-11-04 16:41:04</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>webcast-links-from-community-living-ontarios-62nd-annual-conference</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<category domain="category" nicename="general"><![CDATA[General]]></category>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[5]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Empowering Students to Become Agents of Change</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=513</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 09 Nov 2015 19:17:08 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=513</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;"><img class="aligncenter" src="http://i1.createsend1.com/ei/r/4C/93B/6B0/csimport/reaction4inclusion.073626.jpg" alt="" width="509" height="302" /></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zijkjkt-l-k/" target="_blank">Community Living Ontario</a></strong>’s youth leadership initiative <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zijkjkt-l-u/" target="_blank">Re:Action4Inclusion</a></strong> continues to develop a strong network of young people that are committed to advocating for and alongside their peers who have an intellectual disability, both inside and outside the classroom.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">A key component in creating awareness around advocacy is the Re:Action4Inclusion conference, held annually in Orillia. This year’s event, which takes place on <strong>November 20th to the 22nd</strong>, will provide students with a weekend of networking, exciting guest speakers and workshops that enables them to become powerful agents of change in their own communities.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Many of Community Living Ontario’s member associations, like <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zijkjkt-l-o/" target="_blank">South-East Grey Support Services </a></strong>and <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zijkjkt-l-b/" target="_blank">Community Living Grimsby, Lincoln and West Lincoln</a></strong>, support young people to attend the conference and see it as an opportunity for youth to become engaged in the conversation around inclusion.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“They can create change in the culture of their school and that change does not have to be created strictly by school boards, principals or teachers, but can be achieved by the students themselves,” says<strong>Marsha Ferguson</strong>, Executive Assistant with South-East Grey Support Services.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">She says that by participating in the conference, students are engaging with their peers and gaining a perspective that they may not have experienced otherwise. Ferguson adds that students soon realize that there are others also wanting to influence the way that society views individuals with a disability.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“With having the experience of meeting youth leaders that have been diagnosed with a disability and seeing how successful they are, once given the opportunity to succeed, the students are able to see the potential that all youth have, with or without a disability.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Debra Grieve-Knight</strong>, Community Partnership Coordinator with Community Living Grimsby, Lincoln and West Lincoln, says her association actively connects with secondary schools to promote the Re:Action4Inclusion conference and encourages students to participate.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Over the years, Grieve-Knight says they have sponsored more than 40 students to attend the conference, because it brings together high school students from across the province and challenges them to look closely at how attitudes and actions shape a community.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“This conference also inspires youth to be the catalyst that promotes positive changes of the attitudes and actions in their community. Our agency is honoured to have the opportunity to support the Re:Action4Inclusion movement and proud to be a part of empowering youth to make important and positive societal change.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Ferguson says students in her area that participated in last year’s conference are working on change projects at Grey Highlands Secondary School in Flesherton and inspiring others to become more inclusive.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“They have taken what they have learned from the conference and worked together to create a more inclusive and welcoming environment within their school, as well as to help educate their peers. These change projects are creating a domino effect, inspiring others to also become more inclusive.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">She feels strongly that without having attended the conference, students would not have been as inspired or driven to make this change or have had the tools to know how to become youth advocates.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Grieve-Knight says students from her area returned from the conference with a new outlook on equality, rights, respect and dignity.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Our agency feels that by supporting Re:Action4Inclusion, we are making an immediate positive impact in our community and are laying the groundwork that will shape the future. The conference can inspire the youth in their community to individually and collectively promote inclusion and to be part of a movement that is focused on students working together to strive for an educational experience that truly recognizes and celebrates the abilities of all students.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Ferguson, a Re:Action4Inclusion ally who has attended the conference in the past, finds it inspiring to witness the passion and drive of students that participate.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Seeing students that are so excited about including their peers with a disability reinforces that the message being sent about inclusion from Community Living Ontario, as well as local associations is being heard by today’s youth.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">For information on programming, accommodations, guest speakers and to register for the Re:Action4Inclusion conference, contact <strong>La Toya Morgan</strong>, Provincial Youth Development Coordinator at 416-447-4348 ext. 249 or visit the conference website by clicking <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zijkjkt-l-n/" target="_blank">here</a></strong>.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Check out the video message from Re:Action4Inclusion guest speaker, <strong>Carlos Taguba</strong> of <em>Ill Skillz.</em></p>
<iframe src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/8pxEe0tq3k8" width="560" height="315" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-11-09 19:17:08</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>empowering-students-to-become-agents-of-change</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Class Action Settlement Reached Involving Former Residents of a Dozen Institutions</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=519</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 16 Nov 2015 16:38:50 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=519</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/institutions.jpg"><img class="alignleft wp-image-520 size-medium" src="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/institutions-300x142.jpg" alt="institutions" width="300" height="142" /></a>

A tentative agreement has been reached in a class action lawsuit involving the Ontario government and former residents of <strong>12 institutions</strong> in the province.

The deal was made public yesterday (November 12) and the province has agreed to pay $36 million to settle the class action, which includes claims, class proceedings fund levy, legal costs and disbursements.

The suit alleged that the province was negligent in the management and operation of the facilities, resulting in abuse and harm to former residents.

The Ontario Superior Court of Justice must still approve the proposed settlement agreement. According to Koskie Minsky’s website, the firm representing former residents, a hearing will take place in the coming months, however no specific date was given.

The tentative deal is very similar to the class action settlements for former residents of <strong>Huronia</strong>, <strong>Rideau</strong> and <strong>Southwestern Regional Centres</strong>. Those agreements totalled $67.7 million.

Like in the previous settlements, claimants will have to fill out a form consisting of two sections, A and B. Section A will require that former residents declare they suffered harm while living at one of the 12 institutions. Section B will allow to people to make specific allegations of harm, however they will be required to provide details of the harm suffered and any supporting documents, if available.

Compensation amounts will be determined using a Points Allocation System. The maximum amount each person can receive is $35,000 for each facility. A claims administrator will determine the points assigned, based on the form and supporting documents. Claimants who complete only Section A will receive $2,000.

Former residents will also be able to request their personal files from the province in order to submit their claims.

As part of the previous settlements, commemorative plaques were installed at or near Huronia, Southwestern and Rideau Regional Centres to honour the memory of the former residents. No such stipulation was outlined in the tentative agreement.

The proposed members of the class action are people alive as of <strong>June 16, 2012</strong> and who lived at the following institutions over a speficic period of time:
<ul>
	<li>Adult Occupational Centre (Edgar), between January 1, 1966 and March 31, 1999</li>
	<li>Bluewater Centre (Goderich), between April 1, 1976 and December 20, 1983</li>
	<li>D'Arcy Place (Cobourg), between September 1, 1963 and December 31, 1996</li>
	<li>Durham Centre for the Developmentally Handicapped (Whitby), between April 1, 1974 and September 28, 1986</li>
	<li>L.S. Penrose Centre (Kingston), between April 1, 1974 and March 31, 1977</li>
	<li>Midwestern Regional Centre (Palmerston), between September 1, 1963 and March 31, 1998</li>
	<li>Muskoka Centre (Gravenhurst), between August 28, 1973 and June 30, 1993</li>
	<li>Northwestern Regional Centre (Thunder Bay), between April 1, 1974 and March 31, 1994</li>
	<li>Oxford Mental Health Centre (Woodstock), between January 1, 1969 and March 31, 1974</li>
	<li>Oxford Regional Centre (Woodstock), between April 1, 1974 and March 31, 1996</li>
	<li>Pine Ridge Centre (Aurora), between September 1, 1963 and August 31, 1984</li>
	<li>Prince Edward Heights (Picton), between January 1, 1971 and December 31, 1999</li>
	<li>St. Lawrence Regional Centre (Brockville), between April 1, 1975 and June 30, 1983.</li>
</ul>
Former residents or family members wanting more information should contact <a href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-iihkhyyhui-k/"><strong>Koskie Minsky</strong></a> at 416-977-8353.

To read the Settlement Agreement, click <strong><a href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-iihkhyyhui-u/">here</a></strong>.

<strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>519</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2015-11-16 11:38:50</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-11-16 16:38:50</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>class-action-settlement-reached-involving-former-residents-of-a-dozen-institutions</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>

	</item>
	<item>
				<title>Innovative Housing Solutions Given Spotlight at Forum</title>
		<link>http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=526</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 19 Nov 2015 18:50:22 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator><![CDATA[rlaroche]]></dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/?p=526</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p style="color: #000000;"><img class="alignleft" src="http://i3.createsend1.com/ei/r/5E/2BE/B9E/csimport/housing.014523.jpg" alt="" width="353" height="209" /></p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The need to address the crisis in affordable and appropriate housing options for adults with intellectual disabilities was front and centre at a housing forum held earlier this week in Toronto.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Hosted by the <strong>Inspired by Our Grassroots Steering Committee</strong>, the <strong>Provincial Executive Directors Coordinating Committee</strong> and <a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-p/"><strong>Community Living Ontario</strong></a>, <em>Ideas to Build On</em> was an extension of last year’s housing forum.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Attendees heard from representatives from the <strong>Ministry of Community and Social Services</strong>, the <strong>Developmental Services Housing Task Force</strong> and 10 of 12 recently announced pilot projects.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The presentations throughout the day allowed people to learn more about the various innovative and collaborative initiatives taking place across the province.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Mary Kopcok</strong> was part of the delegation from Windsor-Essex that received $870,000 over two years for their project, <em>Continuing Housing Innovation in Windsor-Essex</em>.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The funding will enable homes to be either purchased or renovated and secondary suites created. Rent supplements and housing allowances will also be made available to some of the participants.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The initiative is being led by the <strong>Windsor-Essex Innovative Housing Project Advisory Group</strong>, a partnership that includes <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-x/">Community Living Windsor</a></strong>, the <strong>City of Windsor</strong>, <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-m/">Windsor-Essex Brokerage for Personal Supports</a></strong> and the <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-c/">Windsor-Essex Family Network</a></strong>.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Kopcok is a Board member with the Windsor-Essex Family Network and the sister of 29-year-old <strong>Matthew</strong>, one of eight people involved in the project. She was pleased that there’s recognition that families are looking for different options and “something innovative that doesn’t necessarily fall within traditionally funded support from MCSS, in terms of providing housing and supports to adults with intellectual disabilities.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">With the project funding, the family home will be renovated to include a secondary suite for Matthew, something his sister says they’re excited about.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“We’ve always tried to keep Matt in community and as part of our family. We include him in everything and segregated programs have never appealed to him or us, and so we’re very fortunate for the timing of this. It seems to coincide, essentially, with the time we’re thinking Matt wants a place of his own.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Mike Town</strong>, Executive Director of <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-q/">Community Living North Perth</a></strong>, was surprised at the variety of projects that were presented, and he’s looking forward to hearing about the outcomes and what can be shared.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“They were all very different and there are a lot of little pieces that we can all take away from. I’m from a rural town in Listowel, and to be able to afford to live on your own, but yet have some supports in your life, is sometimes hard to come by.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Community Living North Perth and <strong>Habitat for Humanity</strong> received $60,000 in funding over two years to create an affordable housing option for two gentlemen with intellectual disabilities. Habitat for Humanity will build a semi-detached house where they will live on their own and a family will occupy the other half.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Habitat for Humanity provides houses for people that have income difficulties and they are going to help our organization with the mortgage,” added Town. “It’ll be interest free, which will help the gentlemen afford, based on their ODSP capabilities, to live in an affordable house that’s brand new.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>Sandra McNamara</strong>, Executive Director of <strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-a/">Community Living North Grenville</a></strong>, also attended the forum. She says her association is trying to determine whether it will continue to offer residential supports or provide strictly support services.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“I’m really interested in how you create a separate entity or a housing task force or a housing corporation, and not just for us, but for affordable housing in our own community.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">McNamara says her organization did not submit one of the 80 proposals during the first round of expressions of interest, but she does anticipate putting forward a proposal for the next round.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">She also sees the discussion on housing as an opportunity for community partnerships and “working with builders, our township and mental health service providers, with a focus to bring them all together to determine how to build affordable housing in North Grenville.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">The second call for expressions of interest is expected in the coming months. <strong>Ron Pruessen</strong>, Chair of the Developmental Services Housing Task Force, says they will be making a recommendation to the Ministry of Community and Social Services on dates for the announcement and deadline for proposals.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“[The process] went pretty smoothly the last time. My guess is that probably after Friday’s meeting (November 13), we may need another two to three, maybe even four weeks, depending on how things are backed up at the Ministry level to get the formal approval for the announcement date and the proposal deadline. I would find it very hard to imagine that we won’t have the announcement by the middle of December, and that we won’t have a proposal deadline at some point in February.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">During his presentation, Pruessen encouraged attendees to continue to pressure the government by advocating and coming up with new ideas. He also shared that he’s confident one of the Task Force’s recommendations to the Ministry of Community and Social Services will be that it continue in some capacity.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">“Something like the Housing Task Force, people outside of the Ministry with a wide range of experience, need to keep contributing to the discussion, making recommendations and continue to have resources to work with. I find it hard to imagine that the Ministry wouldn’t see the logic of that. Technically speaking this is a two-year initiative, the Housing Task Force, but I have a strong feeling that it’s going to continue after that.”</p>
<p style="color: #000000;">Details on the various projects are available by clicking on the links below.</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a href="http://www.communitylivingontario.ca/CLO_blog/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/HousingDRevised-Nov-19.pptx">Housing D Project</a></strong>- Partners for Planning</p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-f/">Bridges to Housing Project</a> </strong>- <em>City of Toronto, Community Living Toronto and InnerCity Family Health Team</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-z/">Community Hub Residential Model </a></strong>- <em>Community Living Campbellford/Brighton and Campbellford Memorial Hospital</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-v/">Imaginative Living Options</a></strong><em> - Community Living Brant and City of Brantford Housing Department</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-e/"><strong>I</strong></a><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-s/">ntensive Individualized </a></strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-yh/"><strong>Support Project</strong></a><em><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-yk/"> </a>- Montage Support Services and Family Service Toronto</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-yu/">Peterborough Transition-Aged Youth Transitional Housing Pilot Project</a> </strong>- <em>Canadian Mental Health Association and Community Living organizations in Peterborough, Haliburton and Kawartha Lakes</em></p>
<strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-jr/">Neighbourly Homes</a></strong> – <em>Community Living St. Marys and Area, City of Stratford, Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation and Habitat for Humanity</em>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-jy/">Housing Trust Project</a></strong> – <em>Citizen Advocacy Ottawa and Families Matter Cooperative</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong><a style="color: #0074c8;" href="http://eblast.gotenzing.com/t/r-l-zdhpo-l-jj/">Moving East</a></strong><strong> </strong>- <em>Durham Association for Family Respite Services, Brockville Association for Community Involvement, Community Involvement Legacy Homes and Intentionally Built Community.</em></p>
<p style="color: #000000;"><strong>- Ron Laroche, Community Living Ontario</strong></p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>526</wp:post_id>

		<wp:post_date_gmt>2015-11-19 18:50:22</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
